    Tetrahydrofuran-Based Transient Receptor Potential Ankyrin 1 (TRPA1) Antagonists: Ligand-Based Discovery, Activity in a Rodent Asthma Model, and Mechanism-of-Action via Cryogenic Electron Microscopy

    • Jack A. Terrett*
      Jack A. Terrett
      Department of Discovery Chemistry, Genentech, Inc., 1 DNA Way, South San Francisco, California 94080, United States

    Abstract

    Transient receptor potential ankyrin 1 (TRPA1) is a nonselective calcium-permeable ion channel highly expressed in the primary sensory neurons functioning as a polymodal sensor for exogenous and endogenous stimuli and has generated widespread interest as a target for inhibition due to its implication in neuropathic pain and respiratory disease. Herein, we describe the optimization of a series of potent, selective, and orally bioavailable TRPA1 small molecule antagonists, leading to the discovery of a novel tetrahydrofuran-based linker. Given the balance of physicochemical properties and strong in vivo target engagement in a rat AITC-induced pain assay, compound 20 was progressed into a guinea pig ovalbumin asthma model where it exhibited significant dose-dependent reduction of inflammatory response. Furthermore, the structure of the TRPA1 channel bound to compound 21 was determined via cryogenic electron microscopy to a resolution of 3 Å, revealing the binding site and mechanism of action for this class of antagonists.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Transient receptor potential ankyrin 1 (TRPA1) is a cation-selective calcium-permeable ion channel that forms a unique branch within the TRP family of ion channels.(1,2) The TRPA1 protein organizes as a homotetramer, with each subunit containing six transmembrane helices that form a central pore surrounded by voltage-sensor-like domains, as well as a large intracellular domain formed by a set of N-terminal ankyrin repeats and a C-terminal extension.(3,4) Highly expressed in the primary sensory neurons, TRPA1 is activated by a range of endogenous and exogenous stimuli, thereby acting as a sensor for pain and inflammation.(3,5) Specifically, TRPA1 is known to be activated by external irritants such as allyl isothiocyanate (AITC), allicin, and cinnamaldehyde, which function as agonists to activate the channel through covalent modification of the cysteine residues in the N-terminal ankyrin repeats, resulting in increased calcium flux and a subsequent pain response.(6−10)
    Recently, there has been a growing interest in targeting TRPA1 with selective antagonists as a potential treatment for neuropathic pain due to several key preclinical studies. TRPA1 knock-out (KO) models in mice have shown that exposure to TRPA1 agonists, such as AITC, formalin, and 4-hydroxynonenal, as well as tactile force, all result in reduced nocifensive behaviors, implicating the ion channel’s role in pain signaling.(11−13) Furthermore, a gain-of-function TRPA1 mutation in humans has been linked to familial episodic pain syndrome (FEPS), providing strong evidence for the role of TRPA1 in pain signaling.(14) To this end, multiple groups have reported small molecule inhibitors of TRPA1 with potent in vitro activity that have been shown to reduce pain in rodent target engagement pain models.(15−25) Despite this progress, successful translation of TRPA1 antagonists as analgesics to a clinical setting has yet to be achieved and only limited efficacy has been demonstrated in rat in vivo pain models.(26) In fact, a recent rat TRPA1 KO study showed normal behavioral responses in multiple pain models, in contrast to previous studies with mice and guinea pigs, casting doubt over the TRPA1 dependence of pain responses in rats.(27)
    Over the past decade, there has been a renewed focus on targeting TRPA1 as a potential treatment for respiratory diseases such as asthma because of several reports that implicate its role in neuroinflammatory pathways.(28) Notably, expression of TRPA1 in the sensory neurons of airways and lung smooth muscles suggest that it could function as a sensor for inhaled irritants, resulting in an inflammatory response.(29,30) Several rodent TRPA1 KO studies have shown a decreased inflammatory response in an ovalbumin-sensitized asthma model following an OVA challenge.(27,31) Additionally, a known TRPA1 antagonist, HC-030031, has been shown to reduce cough responses in a guinea pig cough model.(32)
    Given the potential therapeutic benefit of selectively targeting TRPA1 in the context of asthma, we sought to develop an orally bioavailable and potent antagonist that demonstrated in vivo target engagement and efficacy in both AITC-induced pain and OVA-sensitized asthma models. We recently reported a series of proline sulfonamide-based TRPA1 antagonists that showed robust in vivo target engagement in a rat AITC pain model.(33) Nevertheless, we set out to improve upon this series by identifying a structurally differentiated antagonist with a more balanced physicochemical profile to increase in vivo exposure. Herein, we report on the discovery and optimization of a novel series of TRPA1 inhibitors showing activity in a rodent OVA-sensitized asthma model.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In an effort to find a novel and structurally diverse antagonist for TRPA1, we evaluated literature and were pleased to discover compound 1, a potent and selective antagonist of TRPA1 with promising pharmacokinetic properties and in vivo target engagement (Figure 1).(22) With compound 1 as a starting point, we set about improving TRPA1 potency and optimizing its properties in an effort to improve drug-like attributes. Although significant advances have been made in the study of TRPA1 using cryogenic electron microscopy (cryoEM),(4,34) we were not structurally enabled at the onset of this project and therefore focused our efforts on ligand-based design using energy-minimized conformations and pharmacophores to drive our structure–activity relationships (SAR).
    At the outset, we evaluated a wide range of modifications to the left-hand side, core, linker and right-hand side portions of compound 1 in an effort to improve in vitro potency. Our optimization efforts led us to compound 2, containing an oxadiazolone core and fluoro-substituted phenethyl linker (Figure 1). Compound 2 exhibited a 0.020 μM IC50 against hTRPA1, a 5-fold improvement over compound 1, as well as promising in vitro metabolic stability and drug-like properties (HLM = 5.6 mL/min/kg, LogD7.4 = 1.2). The more polar oxadiazolone core resulted in a higher lipophilic ligand efficiency for the molecule (LLE = 6.5) while facilitating rapid modification of the linker and right-hand side portion of the molecule, given the improved synthetic accessibility. Importantly, the installation of a fluoro-substituent at the benzylic position on compound 2 played a key role in not just improving TRPA1 potency but also metabolic stability (the des-fluoro matched pair had moderate human and rat metabolic stability). We hypothesize that the placement of a benzylic fluorine blocks a possible site of oxidation while minimizing changes in the ethyl linker conformation. This improvement was also manifested in vivo as compound 2 demonstrated promising rat PK, with a clearance of 17 mL/min/kg, 1.4 h half-life, 1.3 L/kg volume of distribution, and a bioavailability of 53%. Nevertheless, we were disappointed to learn that compound 2 is prone to reactive metabolite formation and was flagged as positive in our glutathione (GSH) trapping assay.(35,36) This GSH adduct is hypothesized to be formed through an unknown reactive intermediate during CYP-mediated oxidative defluorination initiated by benzylic oxidation and elimination of fluoride to generate an aryl ketone metabolite.
    Encouraged by the promising profile of compound 2, we sought to further drive down the in vitro TRPA1 potency through additional modifications to the molecule scaffold. Previous SAR leading up to 2 had demonstrated that the “step-like” conformation on the ethyl linker, as can be observed in Figure 1, was essential for a high level of TRPA1 inhibition. We envisioned that rigidification of the linker to maximize this step-like conformation could be accomplished by reducing the free rotation around the benzylic-homobenzylic C–C bond. This strategy could potentially reduce the entropic cost of the molecule positioning into this step-like orientation and therefore improve the binding affinity. To this end, we synthesized a range of saturated cyclic linkers in which we incorporated cyclobutane, cyclopentane, and cyclohexane (compounds 3–5, respectively, Table 1). We were satisfied to observe that, for the trans-cyclobutyl and trans-cyclopentyl linkers (3 and 4), high levels of potency were obtained (0.0074 and 0.0096 μM, respectively) while maintaining good lipophilic ligand efficiency values (5.7 and 5.6). In addition to rigidification, the lower LLE of compounds 3 and 4 relative to compound 2 (LLE = 6.5) suggests that increased lipophilicity may be contributing to the improved TRPA1 potency. Conversely, the cyclohexyl linker 5 was inactive (>20 μM) presumably due to the greatly increased flexibility and extended length of the linker. It is worth noting that the cis diastereomers of these cyclic linkers were all inactive (>20 μM), further pointing to the requirement that a step-like orientation must be maintained for binding to TRPA1.
    Table 1. Evolution of the Saturated Cyclic Linker
    We recognized that additional rigidification of the step-like linker may be able to deliver further improvements in cellular potency, as previously shown by the success of moving from a flexible ethyl adduct to the cyclobutane bridge. Bicyclo[3.1.0]hexanes are known to adopt defined step conformations and have been widely employed in the field of medicinal chemistry to restrict conformational flexibility.(37) At first, we evaluated fused [3.1.0] bicyclic linker 6 but did not observe an improvement in TRPA1 potency (0.032 μM, Table 2). Low-energy conformational analysis of compound 3 overlaid with 6 suggested that the ideal step orientation to enable comparable aryl group overlap could be accomplished if the aryl group was not fused with the bicyclo[3.1.0] linker. With that design hypothesis in mind, we were pleased to find that the corresponding azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane linker 7 brought a comparable level of potency to compound 3 while improving overall LLE (0.0029 μM, LLE = 5.6). Compound 7 was further profiled in PK studies, in vivo target engagement, and in vitro toxicology studies. Initial concerns around reactive metabolite formation associated with the aniline motif were confirmed in our GSH trapping assay where this compound was flagged as positive.(35,36) Unfortunately, switching from the aniline to the fully saturated all-carbon analogue 8 resulted in a complete loss of potency, presumably due to the drastically altered projection of the aryl group. However, the unsaturated bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane linker 9 demonstrated significantly improved TRPA1 binding affinity with a cellular potency of 0.0019 μM. We attribute this result to the rigidified step-like conformation of the bicyclic linker while conserving the planarity of the aryl ring relative to the cyclopentene ring. While compound 9 was progressed into in vivo studies, the molecule still possessed potential toxicity liabilities associated with the styrene motif, as demonstrated by a positive flag in the GSH trapping assay. In an effort to de-risk the aniline structural alert of azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane 7, we hypothesized that incorporation of a pyridine ring into the molecule would reduce the propensity to form reactive metabolites. To our satisfaction, compound 10 was not flagged in our GSH trapping assay, while only showing a modest drop in potency (0.025 μM, LLE = 5.8). Additionally, kinetic solubility was significantly improved compared to compounds 7 and 9 (Kin. Sol. = 97 μM) and 10 maintained good metabolic stability (HLM = 7.2 mL/min/kg, RLM = 7.2 mL/min/kg).
    Table 2. Optimization of Bicyclic Linkers on Oxadiazole Core
    Having addressed the solubility and reactive metabolite concerns raised by the introduction of the bicyclic linker, we next sought to improve upon the potency of pyridine 10 by evaluating the left-hand side portion of the molecule (Table 3). It became clear early on in our program that bicyclic heteroaromatic systems at this location were crucial for maintaining TRPA1 affinity. Within this framework, we were disappointed to see that moving to 6,6-systems such as azaquinazolinone 11 and azaphthalizinone 12 resulted in both decreased potency and metabolic stability in human and rat liver microsomes. Similar results were obtained for the imidazotriazinone 13 (0.050 μM). However, we were pleased to see a significant improvement in TRPA1 inhibition was gained through installation of the pyrazolotriazinone 14 (hTRPA1 IC50 = 0.0081 μM). Unfortunately, a concurrent loss of metabolic stability as highlighted by the liver microsome assay (HLM = 15 mL/min/kg, RLM = 32 mL/min/kg) prevented further progression of this molecule.
    Table 3. Evaluation of Left-Hand Side 6,6- and 5,6-Bicyclic Heteroaromatics
    Table 4. Optimization of the Ether Linkage Led to the Discovery of THF Linker 20
    At this point in our lead optimization campaign, we were faced with diverging SAR that presented a challenge in moving toward a clinical candidate. On the one hand, we had a promising molecule in optimal drug-like space with compound 10; however, TRPA1 potency was relatively modest. Conversely, the aniline and alkene scaffolds of 7 and 9 showed single-digit nanomolar potency yet were limited by poor solubility, high LogD7.4, and increased risk for drug-induced liver injury (DILI). Ideally, we wanted to move away from these undesirable properties and therefore made a concerted effort toward a more drug-like space by adding polarity, removing lipophilicity, and lowering LogD7.4. Toward this aim, we hypothesized that an ether linker could be introduced that would increase polarity while maintaining the preferred step-like conformation adopted by compounds 3–14. The addition of a single oxygen atom to our previously validated ethyl linker was not well tolerated, as shown by compound 15 (4.6 μM, Table 4). However, to our surprise, the extended propyl ether linker 16 demonstrated a 300-fold improvement over 15, with promising LLE (0.014 μM, LLE = 6.6). We postulated that a similar linker rigidification approach as discussed earlier in Table 1 could also be applied to this linker scaffold. A further gain in potency was observed with the cyclobutane ether linker 17 (0.0073 μM); however, the corresponding cyclopentane ether 18 showed a disappointing 100-fold decrease in cellular potency (0.410 μM). We attribute this to a combination of overextension of the linker and a change in the projection of the aryl vector resulting in unfavorable positioning in the binding pocket. In an effort to shorten the linker, we postulated that the oxygen atom could be incorporated into the cyclic linker itself while concurrently lowering the LogD7.4 over an all-carbon cyclic linker. We synthesized a series of tetrahydrofuran (THF) containing molecules and were excited to see that 2,4-disubstituted THF 19 was both highly potent and lipophilic ligand efficient (0.002 μM, LLE = 7.1). Despite this early promise, further profiling of compound 19 revealed that it was unstable in both human and rat plasma, with only 76% and 61% remaining after 4 h incubation, respectively. Additional analysis indicated that the oxadiazolone core was susceptible to ring opening in plasma, explaining the poor recovery of the parent molecule in plasma protein binding assays. To circumvent this instability issue, we returned to the oxadiazole core and discovered compound 20, a metabolically stable, subnanomolar inhibitor of TRPA1 (0.0009 μM, LLE = 7.3). This para-chloro analogue showed an almost 10-fold improvement in TRPA1 inhibition over the corresponding para-fluoro compound (21, hTRPA1 IC50 = 0.0076 μM), although both oxadiazole-containing THF compounds had improved metabolic stability over oxadiazolone 19.
    We were pleased to observe that our human TPRA1 inhibition was maintained across a range of distinct linker scaffolds, giving us the opportunity to fine-tune physicochemical properties without sacrificing potency. Figure 2 highlights low-energy quantum mechanical models of a selection of the linkers we evaluated, specifically, cyclobutane (3), bicyclo[3.1.0]hexene (9), and THF (20). As can be seen in the linker overlay in Figure 2D, the step conformation is conserved across subseries, suggestive of its importance as a key pharmacophore in driving down TRPA1 inhibition.
    With the discovery of a diverse set of in vitro active TRPA1 antagonists in hand, we next sought to determine how they performed in an in vivo setting. We advanced several potent molecules with different profiles – compounds 2, 3, 7, 10, 14, and 20 – into oral and intravenous rat PK (Table 5). While all six molecules exhibited promising metabolic stabilities and permeabilities in vitro, they differed in LogD7.4, kinetic solubility, and plasma protein binding, which translated into distinct PK profiles. Notably, compound 7 demonstrated a very low clearance of 4.5 mL/min/kg, which paired with a high volume of distribution (2.3 L/kg) resulted in a relatively long half-life of 6.4 h. Compound 14 had a higher volume than the other profiled compounds (2.8 L/kg), but due to higher clearance (15 mL/min/kg), its half-life was much lower than compound 7 (2.5 h). Like compound 14, oxadiazolone 3 had a moderate half-life of 2.7 h explained by a clearance of 10 mL/min/kg and a volume of distribution of 2.3 L/kg. The remaining three compounds revealed more modest in vivo half-lives (1.4–1.8 h) given slightly higher clearance (12–17 mL/min/kg) and smaller volumes (1.3–2.1 L/kg). Additionally, compounds 2, 3, and 20 possessed much higher bioavailabilities (53, 75, and 90%, respectively) than 7, 10, and 14 (all <40%).
    Table 5. Compound Profiles, Rat PK, and Rat AITC Target Engagement for Compounds 2, 3, 7, 10, 14, and 20
    a

    5 mg/kg.

    b

    PPB was determined in rat with 4 h compound incubation time (compared to standard 24 h) due to compound instability in rat plasma.

    All six compounds were progressed to a well-validated rat AITC-induced pain model to assess in vivo target engagement. After oral dosing of the TRPA1 antagonist (doses included 0.3, 1, 3, 10, and 30 mg/kg), a 0.1% solution of TRPA1 agonist AITC was injected into the hind paw of the rat at the Tmax (approximately 3 h). Nocifensive behaviors (i.e. flinching, licking, shaking, etc.) were then recorded over a 5 min period post-injection. In all cases, a dose-dependent response was observed in which AITC-induced flinching decreased at higher doses with full suppression at the highest dose (Table 5). At each dose, the free drug target multiples (where Cu/rIC50 = the free plasma concentration/rat TRPA1 IC50) were calculated. Despite the observation of a dose-dependent response for all six compounds, we observed that the degree of target coverage necessary to block the AITC-induced pain response varied widely across compounds, a phenomenon also observed with NaV1.7-selective sodium channel blockers.(38)
    Exploring this further, in vivo EC50 values for each compound were calculated based on the behavior response relative to free drug exposure within individual animals and across doses. Compounds 2 and 10 exhibited unbound in vivo EC50 values of 0.390 and 0.220 μM, respectively, compared to the 0.018 μM potency measured for both compounds in the rat TRPA1 in vitro assay. Compounds 3 and 20 possessed unbound EC50 values of 0.049 and 0.053 μM, respectively, in the rat AITC-induced pain study, representing only a modest difference from the measured cellular potencies (3 = 0.014 μM; 20 = 0.0074 μM). Meanwhile, compounds 7 and 14 displayed single-digit nanomolar in vivo potencies (0.0079 and 0.0062 μM, respectively) that correlated well with the measured cellular potencies (0.0079 and 0.0082 μM, respectively).
    We noticed that the discrepancies between in vitro and in vivo potencies appeared to trend with lipophilicity, with less lipophilic molecules possessing lower in vivo potencies than predicted by the cellular assay. Toward this, a recent discussion of the impact of lipophilicity of various small molecule properties highlights that potency may be underestimated in in vitro assays due to nonspecific binding.(39) While this could rationalize the high in vivo potency of higher lipophilicity molecules like 7 and 14, it is more difficult to explain the reduced potency of more polar inhibitors such as 2 and 10. We instead hypothesized that the observed in vitro/in vivo potency differences could be due to the enhanced (or decreased) ability of a molecule to access the membrane-bound receptor in the specific tissues of interest.(40,41) More specifically, those molecules with enhanced tissue (i.e. membrane) partitioning might possess higher observed potencies in vivo.
    To explore this possibility, we evaluated lipophilicity in the context of an unbound volume of distribution (Vss,u), an in vivo parameter measuring drug depot in tissues (where Vss,u = Vss/fu). As Vss,u represents an in vivo measure of drug partitioning in tissues, the in vitro/in vivo potency discrepancies at varying Vss,u may be rationalized assuming the cellular assay does not fully reflect the tissue (or membrane) environment where native TRPA1 receptors reside. From this perspective, the high in vivo potencies of 7 and 14, with the highest measured Vss,u values (128 and 140 L/kg, respectively), could be rationalized by enhanced access to the membrane-bound TRPA1 target.
    Based on the above data, compound 20 was selected for further profiling in an OVA-induced airway inflammation efficacy study(31) as it struck a balance of both desirable PK and physicochemical properties with favorable in vivo potency. Compound 20 demonstrated excellent selectivity over other TRP channels as no activity was observed against TRPV1, TRPM8, or TRPC6 at concentrations up to 20 μM.(42) Furthermore, 20 exhibited minimal off-target activity against ion channels such as hERG, Nav1.5, and Cav1.2 (all <15% inhibition at 10 μM), in a CEREP panel at 10 μM (only 1/100 targets showed >50% inhibition), and against CYP3A4 and CYP2D6 (IC50 >10 μM for both). Guinea pigs are an excellent model to study lung inflammation due to the similarity of their lung architecture and physiology to humans, compared to rats. Importantly, compound 20 exhibited similar in vitro potency against the guinea pig TRPA1 channel to rat (gpTRPA1 IC50 = 0.0071 μM). Guinea pigs received two OVA immunizations, followed by a single OVA challenge. Bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) analysis performed 24 h after OVA challenge reveals a pronounced alveolar infiltration of inflammatory cells predominantly composed of eosinophils with neutrophils and alveolar macrophages. Compound 20 was dosed at 3, 10, and 30 mg/kg orally BID with dexamethasone as a positive control, before and after OVA challenge. Compound 20 administration resulted in a statistically significant dose-dependent reduction of BALF infiltrates in the airways, as shown in Figure 3. This data suggests that TRPA1 inhibition with antagonist 20 is effective at reducing the inflammatory response in a rodent allergic asthma model and represents a promising therapeutic for the treatment of asthma.

    Structural Elucidation of the Binding Site

    In parallel to our medicinal chemistry campaign, we worked to determine structures of ligand-bound human TRPA1 using cryoEM, with the goal to enable structure-based drug design (SBDD). Following optimization of the protein construct as described elsewhere,(43) we were able to solve TRPA1 structures, including one in complex with compound 21 (Figure 4A). The structure, with a resolution of 3 Å, reveals an intracellular antagonist binding site near the interface with the lipid bilayer and provides insights into the mechanism of action.
    The hypoxanthine moiety of compound 21 stacks against preS1, the helix preceding the S1 of the voltage sensor-like domain (VSLD), while the rest of the ligand extends toward the center of the channel and is sandwiched between the TRP helix (below) and the S4-to-S4-S5 linker (above) (Figure 4B). The preS1 side of the pocket is dominated by the π–π stacking interaction between the side chain Trp711 and hypoxanthine, whose carbonyl is also hydrogen-bonded to the side chain of His983 of the TRP helix (Figure 4B). On the other side of the hypoxanthine plane, ligand-receptor interactions are dominated by extensive contacts with the backbone and beta and gamma carbons of Arg852 above the ligand, and with the entire length of the Gln979 side chain below, both of which interact extensively with the oxadiazole core.
    The pocket accommodating the core, THF, and fluorophenyl is largely hydrophobic, with compound 21 making favorable nonpolar van der Waals contacts with Ile858 (backbone and side chain) and Val861 (side chain) of the S4-S5 linker, as well as Val967 (backbone and side chain), Met978 (side chain), and Leu982 (side chain) of the TRP-like helix. In our structure, the fluorophenyl and THF linker appear roughly co-planar, and there are no direct polar interactions with the THF oxygen, suggesting that the primary role of the linker oxygen is to control the position of the right-hand side aryl vector. In comparison to the low-energy QM model for closely related analogue 20 previously outlined in Figure 2C, it is interesting to observe that the THF ring occupies a more co-planar conformation relative to the phenyl ring than was predicted. Nevertheless, the propensity for this THF linker to induce a step-like configuration between oxadiazole and phenyl rings is consistent between the observed structure and calculated model, validating our initial design hypothesis.
    Comparison of our compound 21-hTRPA1 structure to other structures (e.g., Paulsen et al. 2015, Suo et al. 2020)(4,34) reveals that, as expected, we observe the TRPA1 channel in its inactive, closed conformation. A recently published structure of TRPA1 in an activated, open conformation, reveals that channel opening is associated with large motions of the VSLD regions around the pore domain of TRPA1, and with straightening of the S4-S5 linker and S5 helices to form a single long helix.(44) An overlay of this open-state structure (PDB: 6V9X) with our structure reveals that, while the relative positions of Trp711 and the TRP helix remained unchanged, binding site occupancy by compound 21 would sterically prevent straightening of the S4-S5 linker as described by Zhao et al. (Figure 5).(44) This suggests that compound 21 antagonizes TRPA1 channel opening by acting as a molecular wedge, resting atop the TRP helix and against Trp711 of preS1, and thereby blocking the structural transition to the open state. In addition, the intracellular location of the antagonist binding site near the membrane interface supports our hypothesis that enhanced membrane partitioning may impact observed potencies by increasing the local concentration near the binding site.

    Chemistry

    The syntheses of oxadiazolones 2–5 presented in Tables 1 and 2 are depicted in Scheme 1. Oxadiazolone intermediate 34 could be accessed from previously described heteroarene 31(22) via alkylation (→32), hydrazide formation (→33), and CDI-mediated cyclization. Bromination and fluoride trapping of styrene 22 generated brominated phenethyl intermediate 23, which was used to alkylate 34 to form compound 2. The cyclobutanol, cyclopentanol, and cyclohexanol intermediates (28, 29, and 30) were formed via reduction of ketone precursors 25, 26, and 27, respectively. 25 and 27 were available commercially, while 26 was synthesized through a Hayashi coupling to cyclopentenone (24). Mitsunobu reactions of 28, 29, and 30 with 34 led to oxadiazolone compounds 3, 4, and 5.
    Fused bicyclo[3.1.0] compound 6 was synthesized via the route outlined in Scheme 2. Reduction of commercially available indanone 35 (→36), acid-mediated alcohol elimination (→37), and cyclopropanation led to tricyclic ester 38. Ester hydrolysis (→39), amide formation (→40), and amide dehydration formed nitrile 41, which could be converted to oxadiazole 42 via a three-step sequence. Final alkylation with heteroarene 31, followed by separation of stereoisomers, delivered compound 6.
    The syntheses of azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-containing compounds 7 and 10–14 presented in Tables 2 and 3 are shown in Scheme 3. Bicyclic nitrile intermediate 43 was arylated via a Buchwald–Hartwig coupling to intermediate 44 or via an SNAr to intermediate 45. Both intermediates 44 and 45 were converted to oxadiazoles 46 and 47 via a three-step sequence and then alkylated with heteroarenes 31, 54, or 55 to form compounds 7, 10, 11, and 14. 54 and 55 were both synthesized following literature procedures.(22,45) Amide formation from commercially available carboxylic acid 48 (→49), dehydration (→50), and oxadiazole formation led to intermediate 51. Alkylation with previously described 56(46) or 57(45) led to Boc-protected intermediates 52 and 53, which were then deprotected and arylated via nucleophilic aromatic substitution to form oxadiazoles 12 and 13. All carbon bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane compounds 8 and 9, also depicted in Table 2, were synthesized following the sequence outlined in Scheme 4. Starting with commercial cyclopentenol 58, alcohol protection (→59), cyclopropanation (→60), ester hydrolysis (→61), amide formation (→62), and dehydration led to nitrile 63. Subsequent TBAF deprotection (→64), Dess–Martin oxidation (→65), phenylmagnesium chloride addition in the presence of a lanthanide salt (→66), and acid-mediated alcohol elimination generated common alkene intermediate 67. Hydrogenation of alkene 67 gave bicyclic intermediate 68, both of which were taken on to their respective oxadiazoles 69 and 70. Alkylation with heteroarene 31 gave bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane compounds 8 and 9 (after separation of enantiomers).
    Ethers 15–18 presented in Table 4 were synthesized according to Scheme 5. Alkylation of oxadiazolone 34 with commercial alkyl bromides 71 and 72 formed acyclic ether compounds 15 and 16. Cyclobutyl ether 17 was synthesized from cyclobutanone 73 via ketone reduction (→74), tosylate formation (→75), debenzylation (→76), Mitsunobu reaction with 34 (→77), and finally substitution with 3-chlorophenol. This sequence resulted in the trans diastereomer (17) due to early formation of the trans alcohol 74. In contrast, the cyclopentyl ether 18 was formed from the commercially available trans-1,3-diol 78. Monoalcohol protection (→79), Mitsunobu reaction with 3-fluorophenol (→80), TBAF deprotection (→81), and a subsequent Mitsunobu reaction with oxadiazolone intermediate 34 delivered the trans-cyclopentyl ether 18.
    Finally, the synthesis of tetrahydrofuran-containing ethers 19–21 in Table 4 is outlined in Scheme 6. Allylmagnesium chloride addition to benzaldehyde 82 (→83) followed by epoxidation (→84) and cyclization via epoxide opening resulted in THF intermediate 85. Mitsunobu reaction with common intermediate 34 led to oxadiazolone THF compound 19 after separation of stereoisomers. Oxadiazole THF compounds 20 and 21 were synthesized via a similar, modified route to compound 19. Asymmetric iridium-catalyzed allylation of benzaldehydes 82 and 86 formed enantio-enriched allyl alcohols 87 and 88. Subsequent dibromination with Br2 (→89 and 90), base-mediated cyclization (→91 and 92), and cyanide displacement delivered trans 2,4-disubstituted THFs 93 and 94 after separation of diastereomers. Three-step oxadiazole formation (→ 95 and 96) and alkylation with heteroarene 31 resulted in the oxadiazole THF compounds 20 and 21 as single enantiomers.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    With literature compound 1 as a promising starting point, we pursued a lead optimization campaign that ultimately led us to potent THF-containing TRPA1 antagonist 20. QM modeling to evaluate low-energy molecular conformations helped drive a ligand-based design strategy that focused predominantly on rigidification of the “step-like” linker connecting the central oxadiazole/oxadiazolone core and right-hand side aryl ring. Several chemotypes were evaluated including ethyl linkers (2), cyclobutanes (3), and bicyclic [3.1.0] systems (such as 7 and 9), which contributed to the discovery of THF compounds 20 and 21. Six compounds with distinct profiles were evaluated in vivo in rat PK and an AITC-induced rat target engagement pain model, which supported the selection of compound 20 for further in vivo profiling in a preclinical guinea pig ovalbumin asthma model. Compound 20 showed a significant reduction in inflammatory response at all dose levels following guinea pig OVA challenge, comparable to the dexamethasone positive control. This data provides additional evidence to support the role of TRPA1 in asthma and highlights compound 20 as an important in vivo tool molecule for the continued development of small molecule TRPA1 antagonists with potential clinical applications. Furthermore, cryoEM revealed the binding site and mechanism of action of compound 21 on the TRPA1 ion channel and should help promote future structure-based design efforts for TRPA1 antagonist optimization. Further development of this series of TRPA1 antagonists and their efficacy in preclinical asthma and other inflammatory models will be reported in due course.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Methods

    All commercial solvents and reagents were used without additional purification unless indicated otherwise. Intermediates 22, 25, 27, 48, 58, 71–73, and 78 were acquired via commercial sources. 1H NMR spectra were measured on Bruker Avance III 300, 400, or 500 MHz spectrometers, and 13C NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance III 101 MHz spectrometer. Chemical shifts (in ppm) were referenced to tetramethylsilane as an internal standard (δ = 0 ppm). Reaction progress was monitored by either a Shimadzu LCMS/UV system with an LC-30 AD solvent pump, Sil-30 AC autosampler, 2020 MS, SPD-M30A UV detector, and CTO-20A column oven, using 2–98% acetonitrile/0.1% formic acid (or 0.01% ammonia) over 2.5 min or a Waters Acquity LCMS system using 2–98% acetonitrile/0.1% formic acid (or 0.1% ammonia) over 2 min. Flash column chromatography purifications were performed using a Teledyne Isco Combiflash Rf and Silicycle HP columns. Reverse-phase purification was done on a Phenomenex Gemini-NX C18 (30 × 100 mm, 5 μm) with a gradient of 5–95% acetonitrile/water (with 0.1% NH4OH or 0.1% formic acid) at 60 mL/min over 10 min. Preparative SFC separations were carried out on a PIC Solutions instrument, with conditions specified in the Experimental Section. High-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) of final compounds was obtained on a Thermo UHPLC/QE with a Thermo-Q Exactive mass spectrometry detector using ESI ionization, following elution on an Acquity BEH C18 stationary phase (2.1 mm × 50 mm; 1.7 μm particle size) using a gradient of water/acetonitrile (3–97% over 7 min with 0.1% formic acid in both phases). Unless stated otherwise, analytical purity was >95% as determined by LCMS using UV 254 nm detection.

    1-(2-Bromo-1-fluoroethyl)-4-chlorobenzene (23)

    Et3N·3HF (4.89 g, 30.3 mmol) was added dropwise into a mixture of 1-chloro-4-ethenylbenzene (3.00 g, 21.7 mmol), NBS (5.78 g, 32.5 mmol), and DCM (30 mL) with stirring at 0 °C under nitrogen. The resulting solution was stirred overnight at room temperature. The resulting solution was diluted with ethyl acetate, washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatograhy eluting with petroleum ether to afford the title compound (2.0 g, 39% yield) as a yellow oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.42 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.33 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 5.70–5.56 (m, 1H), 3.73–3.57 (m, 2H).

    Methyl 2-(7-Methyl-6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl) Acetate (32)

    A mixture of 7-methyl-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-6-one (2.00 g, 13.3 mmol), methyl 2-chloroacetate (1.44 g, 13.3 mmol), DMF (50 mL), Cs2CO3 (6.50 g, 20.0 mmol), and TBAI (49 mg, 0.13 mmol) was stirred for 1 h at 60 °C. The resulting mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by a silica gel column eluting with DCM/MeOH (10:1) to afford the title compound (1.3 g, 44% yield) as a light yellow solid. LCMS, m/z = 223 [M + H]+.

    2-(7-Methyl-6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl) Acetohydrazide (33)

    A mixture of methyl 2-(7-methyl-6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl)acetate (666 mg, 3.00 mmol), MeOH (10 mL), and hydrazine hydrate (1.55 g, 80%) was stirred overnight at 80 °C. The resulting mixture was concentrated under vacuum to afford the title compound (550 mg, 83% yield) as a light yellow solid. LCMS, m/z = 223 [M + H]+.

    5-[(7-Methyl-6-oxo-purin-1-yl)methyl]-3H-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-one (34)

    A mixture of hydrazide 33 (222 mg, 1.00 mmol), DMF (5 mL), and CDI (178 mg, 1.10 mmol) was stirred for 3 h at room temperature. This resulted in a light brown solution of the title compound in DMF, which was used for the next step without any further purification. LCMS, m/z = 249 [M + H]+.

    (R)-3-(2-(4-Chlorophenyl)-2-fluoroethyl)-5-((7-methyl-6-oxo-6H-purin-1(7H)-yl)methyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2(3H)-one (2)

    The solution of oxadiazolone 34 (∼0.2 M, 6 mL) was added dropwise into a mixture of 1-(2-bromo-1-fluoroethyl)-4-chlorobenzene (1.15 mg, 4.84 mmol), TBAI (45 mg, 0.12 mmol), K2CO3 (1.00 g, 7.25 mmol), and DMF (4 mL) at room temperature. The mixture was stirred for 12 h at 60 °C. The solids were filtered out. The resulting solution was purified on a C18 column eluting with CH3CN/H2O (10 mmol/L NH4HCO3) increasing from 5 to 95% over 30 min. This resulted in 15 mg of a racemic mixture. The product was then purified by Chiral-Prep-HPLC with the following conditions: column, Chiralpak IA, 2 × 25 cm, 5 μm; mobile phase, Hex/EtOH (hold 50% ethanol over 28 min); detector, UV 220/254 nm. This resulted in 3.4 mg of the title compound as a white solid. Rt = 6.7 min (Repaired IA, 0.46 × 10 cm, 5 μm, (hexane/DCM = 5:1)(0.1% DEA):EtOH = 50:50, 1.0 mL/min). HRMS m/z calcd for C17H15ClFN6O3 [M + H]+: 405.0873. Found: 405.0863. HPLC purity: 99.20%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.35 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.45 (s, 4H), 5.83 (ddd, J = 47.5, 7.9, 3.2 Hz, 1H), 5.25 (s, 2H), 4.24–3.99 (m, 2H), 3.98 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 156.4, 153.4, 152.9, 151.7, 147.2, 145.2, 134.9 (d, J = 19.2 Hz), 133.7 (d, J = 2.8 Hz), 128.6, 128.1 (d, J = 6.2 Hz), 114.6, 90.0 (d, J = 174.8 Hz), 49.7 (d, J = 25.0 Hz), 40.3, 33.4.

    3-(4-Chlorophenyl)cyclobutanol (28)

    Sodium borohydride (66.4 mg, 1.76 mmol) was added to a solution of 3-(4-chlorophenyl)cyclobutanone (317 mg, 1.76 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL). The reaction was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The reaction was quenched with water at 0 °C and extracted with iPrOAc (three times). The combined organic extracts were washed with brine, dried with anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The crude mixture was purified by silica gel chromatography with 0–70% iPrOAc/heptane to afford the title compound (280 mg, 87% yield) as a clear oil. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 7.35–7.30 (m, 2H), 7.27–7.21 (m, 2H), 5.14 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 4.11–3.99 (m, 1H), 2.91–2.80 (m, 1H), 2.65–2.55 (m, 2H), 1.90–1.83 (m, 2H).

    3-[3-(4-Chlorophenyl)cyclobutyl]-5-[(7-methyl-6-oxo-purin-1-yl)methyl]-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-one (3)

    DIAD (162 μL, 0.81 mmol) was added to a solution of oxadiazolone 34 (100 mg, 0.40 mmol), 3-(4-chlorophenyl)cyclobutanol (147 mg, 0.81 mmol), and triphenylphosphine resin bound (2.25 mmol/g) (358 mg, 0.81 mmol) in THF (2.7 mL) at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The reaction was filtered through Celite and concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was purified by SFC using a Chiralpak IA column with 45% of 0.1% ammonium hydroxide in MeOH in CO2. This resulted in the title compound (41.9 mg, 25% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C19H18ClN6O3 [M + H]+: 413.1123. Found: 413.1118. HPLC purity: 96.90%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.37 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.37 (s, 4H), 5.27 (s, 2H), 4.65 (ddt, J = 8.4, 6.5, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 3.98 (s, 3H), 3.63 (ddt, J = 11.3, 8.5, 5.0 Hz, 1H), 2.85–2.67 (m, 2H), 2.56–2.44 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 156.4, 153.5, 152.0, 151.4, 147.2, 145.2, 143.4, 130.6, 128.5, 128.3, 114.6, 47.8, 40.3, 34.0, 33.4, 32.7.

    3-(4-Chlorophenyl)cyclopentanone (26)

    To a 150 mL pressure vessel charged with acetylacetonatobis(ethylene)rhodium (I) (157 mg, 0.610 mmol), (rac)-BINAP (379 mg, 0.610 mmol), and (4-chlorophenyl)boronic acid (6.80 mL, 42.6 mmol) were added 1,4-dioxane (32 mL), water (3.2 mL), and cyclopent-2-enone (1.0 mL, 12 mmol). The mixture was bubbled with nitrogen for 10 min and stirred at 100 °C for 5 h. More acetylacetonatobis(ethylene)rhodium (I) (157 mg, 0.610 mmol) and (rac)-BINAP (379 mg, 0.610 mmol) were added; the reaction mixture was bubbled with nitrogen for 10 min and heated at 110 °C for 5 h. The solvent was evaporated, and diethyl ether was added. The remaining solids were filtered off, and the filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure. The obtained residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (ethyl acetate in hexanes, 10–15% gradient) to afford the title compound (1.15 g, 49% yield) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.34–7.28 (m, 2H), 7.21–7.16 (m, 2H), 3.46–3.35 (m, 1H), 2.66 (dd, J = 18.2, 7.4 Hz, 1H), 2.52–2.39 (m, 2H), 2.37–2.24 (m, 2H), 2.01–1.88 (m, 1H).

    3-(4-Chlorophenyl)cyclopentanol (29)

    Sodium borohydride (117 mg, 3.08 mmol) was added to a solution of 3-(4-chlorophenyl)cyclopentanone (400 mg, 2.05 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL) at 0 °C, and the resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min. A saturated aqueous solution of NH4Cl (40 mL) was slowly added, and the mixture was stirred for 20 min. It was extracted with DCM (3 × 25 mL), and the combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure to give the title compound (380 mg, 94% yield) as a mixture of diastereomers (ratio 1.5:1). The product was used as is for the next step. 1H NMR of the 1.5:1 (60:40) diastereomeric mixture listed as major/minor (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.27–7.20 (m, 3H), 7.18–7.14 (m, 1H), 4.55–4.49 (minor, m, 0.4 H), 4.50–4.41 (major, m, 0.6H), 3.44–3.30 (minor, m, 0.4H), 3.07–2.97 (major, m, 0.6H), 2.46 (major, ddd, J = 14.4, 8.4, 6.4 Hz, 0.6H), 2.30–2.15 (m, 1H), 2.11–2.01 (m, 1H), 1.99–1.74 (m, 2H), 1.74–1.66 (minor, m, 0.4H), 1.66–1.56 (m, 1H), 1.46 (major, d, J = 3.4 Hz, 0.6H), 1.40 (minor, d, J = 3.0 Hz, 0.4H).

    5-[(7-Methyl-6-oxo-purin-1-yl)methyl]-3-[(1R,3R)-3-(4-chlorophenyl)cyclopentyl]-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-one (4)

    To a solution of 3-(4-chlorophenyl)cyclopentanol (180 mg, 0.920 mmol), oxadiazolone 34 (318 mg, 1.28 mmol), and triphenylphosphine (312 mg, 1.19 mmol) in DMF (6.8 mL) was added diisopropyl azodicarboxylate (0.23 mL, 1.2 mmol) dropwise at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15 h. Most of the DMF was evaporated, and the resulting material was purified by silica gel chromatography (MeOH in DCM, 1–8% gradient) to afford the title compound (296 mg, 76% yield) as a racemic mixture of diastereomers. The resulting 4 isomers were separated by SFC with the following conditions: column, AD, 10 × 250 mm, 5 μm; isocratic 55% MeOH, 10 mL/min; 100 bar; column temperature: 35 °C; run time: 15 min. The title compound was obtained as a white solid as the fourth eluting compound (Rt = 12.7 min.). LCMS, m/z = 427.0 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.35 (s, 1H), 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.34 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.27 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 5.24 (s, 2H), 4.67–4.57 (m, 1H), 3.97 (s, 3H), 3.30–3.18 (m, 1H), 2.29–2.08 (m, 3H), 2.07–1.96 (m, 1H), 1.96–1.83 (m, 1H), 1.69–1.51 (m, 1H).

    (1S,4S)-4-(4-Chlorophenyl)cyclohexan-1-ol (30)

    To a 0 °C solution of 4-(4-chlorophenyl)cyclohexanone (500 mg, 2.40 mmol) in MeOH (6 mL) was added sodium borohydride (109 mg, 2.88 mmol). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2.5 h. Isopropyl acetate was added, and the mixture was washed with H2O and brine. The organic layer was concentrated in vacuo and then purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 0–100% isopropyl acetate in heptane. The desired cis diastereomer eluted first and was concentrated to afford 62 mg as a yellow oil (12% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.27–7.23 (m, 2H), 7.19–7.14 (m, 2H), 4.13 (td, J = 3.1, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 2.51 (tt, J = 11.5, 3.2 Hz, 1H), 1.94–1.78 (m, 4H), 1.73–1.59 (m, 4H).

    5-[(7-Methyl-6-oxo-purin-1-yl)methyl]-3-[(1R,4R)-4-(4-chlorophenyl)cyclohexyl]-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-one (5)

    DIAD (61.1 mg, 0.302 mmol) was added to a solution of oxadiazolone 34 (50 mg, 0.201 mmol), (1S,4S)-4-(4-chlorophenyl)cyclohexanol (63.7 mg, 0.302 mmol), and triphenylphosphine (79.3 mg, 0.302 mmol) in THF (1.3 mL) at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 18 h. The crude mixture was concentrated in vacuo and then purified by SFC using a Synergi Polar RP column with 25% of 0.1% ammonium hydroxide in methanol in CO2. This afforded the title compound in 11.6 mg as a white solid (13% yield). HRMS m/z calcd for C21H22ClN6O3 [M + H]+: 441.1436. Found: 441.1427. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.35 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.37–7.30 (m, 2H), 7.30–7.23 (m, 2H), 5.23 (s, 2H), 3.97 (s, 3H), 3.93 (tt, J = 11.8, 4.0 Hz, 1H), 2.56 (tt, J = 8.5, 4.2 Hz, 1H), 1.96–1.88 (m, 2H), 1.88–1.79 (m, 2H), 1.73 (qd, J = 12.3, 3.0 Hz, 2H), 1.60 (qd, J = 12.3, 3.0 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 156.4, 153.4, 152.2, 151.3, 147.2, 145.3, 145.2, 130.5, 128.6, 128.2, 114.6, 54.0, 41.4, 33.4, 31.9, 31.1, 30.3.

    4-Chloro-2,3-dihydro-1H-inden-1-ol (36)

    Into a 500 mL three-necked round-bottom flask were placed 4-chloro-2,3-dihydro-1H-inden-1-one (10 g, 60.0 mmol), MeOH (100 mL), and NaBH4 (3.5 g, 92.5 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred for 15 min at 0 °C in an ice/salt bath. The resulting solution was allowed to react, with stirring, for an additional 2 h at 25 °C. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of 250 mL of water. The resulting solution was extracted with ethyl acetate, washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. This resulted in 7 g (69% yield) of the title compound as a yellow oil. GCMS, m/z = 168.

    7-Chloro-1H-indene (37)

    Into a 250 mL round-bottom flask were placed 36 (7.00 g, 41.5 mmol), TsOH (720 mg, 4.18 mmol), and THF (20 mL). The resulting solution was stirred for 24 h at 90 °C in an oil bath. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of water. The resulting solution was extracted with ether, washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. This resulted in 6 g (96% yield) of the title compound as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 7.40 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 7.30 (t, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 7.21 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 6.98–6.94 (m, 1H), 6.70–6.66 (m, 1H), 3.42 (s, 2H).

    Ethyl 5-Chloro-1,1a,6,6a-tetrahydrocyclopropa[a]indene-1-carboxylate (38)

    Into a 500 mL three-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed 7-chloro-1H-indene (7.00 g, 46.5 mmol), dichloromethane (100 mL), Rh2(OAc)4 (210 mg, 0.475 mmol), and ethyl 2-diazoacetate (16 g, 140 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred for 1 h at 0 °C in an ice/salt bath and then for 12 h at 25 °C. The reaction progress was monitored by GCMS. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of 500 mL of water. The resulting solution was extracted with dichloromethane and washed with brine. The mixture was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was applied onto a silica gel column with ethyl acetate/petroleum ether (20:1). This resulted in 4.9 g (45% yield) of the title compound as a colorless oil. GCMS, m/z = 236.

    5-Chloro-1,1a,6,6a-tetrahydrocyclopropa[a]indene-1-carboxylic Acid (39)

    Into a 250 mL round-bottom flask were placed ester 38 (4.90 g, 20.7 mmol), MeOH (40 mL), H2O (20 mL), and NaOH (1.66 g, 41.5 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred for 12 h at 70 °C. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of 200 mL of water. The pH value of the solution was adjusted to acidic with 1 N HCl. The resulting solution was extracted with ethyl acetate, washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. This resulted in 2.2 g (51% yield) of the title compound as a yellow solid. LCMS, m/z = 207.1 [M–H]−.

    5-Chloro-1,1a,6,6a-tetrahydrocyclopropa[a]indene-1-carboxamide (40)

    Into a 250 mL round-bottom flask were placed carboxylic acid 39 (2.2 g, 11 mmol), DMF (40 mL), NH4Cl (2.8 g, 52 mmol), HATU (6.1 g, 16 mmol), and DIEA (9.6 g, 74 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred for 3 h at 25 °C. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of 400 mL of water. The resulting solution was extracted with ethyl acetate, washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography using ethyl acetate as the eluent. This resulted in 2 g (91% yield) of the title compound as a yellow solid. LCMS, m/z = 208.2 [M + H]+.

    5-Chloro-1,1a,6,6a-tetrahydrocyclopropa[a]indene-1-carbonitrile (41)

    Into a 250 mL three-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed amide 40 (2.2 g, 11 mmol), DCM (50 mL), triethylamine (3.22 g, 31.8 mmol), and phosphoroyl trichloride (1.94 g, 12.7 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred for 2 h at 0 °C in an ice/salt bath. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of 250 mL of saturated aqueous NaHCO3, extracted with DCM, washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. This resulted in 1.5 g (75% yield) of the title compound as a red oil. GCMS, m/z = 189.

    3-(5-Chloro-1,1a,6,6a-tetrahydrocyclopropa[a]inden-1-yl)-5-(chloromethyl)-1,2,4-oxadiazole (42)

    Into a 250 mL round-bottom flask were placed 41 (1.5 g, 7.9 mmol), EtOH (20 mL), and NH2OH·H2O (4.1 g, 80 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred for 12 h at 80 °C in an oil bath. The resulting mixture was concentrated in vacuo to give 1.7 g (97% yield) of (Z)-5-chloro-N′-hydroxy-1,1a,6,6a-tetrahydrocyclopropa[a]indene-1-carboximidamide as a yellow solid. To a solution of this compound (1.00 g, 4.49 mmol) and triethylamine (910 mg, 8.99 mmol) in acetone (20 mL) at 0 °C was added 2-chloroacetyl chloride (660 mg, 5.84 mmol) dropwise. The resulting solution was stirred for 1 h at 25 °C. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of 200 mL of water. The resulting solution was extracted with ethyl acetate, washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. This resulted in 1.17 g (87% yield) of (Z)-5-chloro-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)-1,1a,6,6a-tetrahydrocyclopropa[a]indene-1-carboximidamide as a red oil, which was added to a 250 mL round-bottom flask along with toluene (20 mL). The resulting solution was stirred for 12 h at 110 °C in an oil bath. The resulting mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography using ethyl acetate/petroleum ether (1:1) as an eluent. This resulted in 500 mg (45% yield) of the title compound as a yellow oil. LCMS, m/z = 281.0 [M + H]+.

    1-((3-((1R,1aS,6aR)-5-Chloro-1,1a,6,6a-tetrahydrocyclopropa[a]inden-1-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-7-methyl-1,7-dihydro-6H-purin-6-one (6)

    Into a 20 mL vial were placed 7-methyl-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-6-one (134 mg, 0.892 mmol), TBAI (33 mg, 0.089 mmol), K2CO3 (370 mg, 2.67 mmol), DMF (8 mL), and oxadiazole 42 (250 mg, 0.889 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred for 3 h at 25 °C. The solids were filtered out. The resulting mixture was concentrated under vacuum. The crude product was purified by RP-HPLC to yield a mixture of stereoisomers, and this was separated by Prep-HPLC with the following conditions: column, XBridge Prep C18 OBD, 19 × 150 mm, 5 μm; mobile phase, water (10 mmol/L NH4HCO3) and MeCN (35% MeCN up to 55% in 7 min); detector, UV 254/220 nm. The crude product was purified by Chiral-Prep-HPLC with the following conditions: column, Chiralpak IC, 2 × 25 cm, 5 μm; mobile phase, MTBE-HPLC and ethanol-HPLC (hold 30% ethanol-HPLC in 20 min); detector, UV 254/220 nm. This resulted in 24.5 mg (7% yield) of the title compound as a white solid. LCMS, m/z = 394 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.44 (s, 1H), 8.24 (s, 1H), 7.38–7.33 (m, 1H), 7.23–7.16 (m, 2H), 5.54 (s, 2H), 3.96 (s, 3H), 3.30–3.10 (m, 2H), 2.98–2.96 (m, 1H), 2.46–2.41 (m, 1H), 1.75 (t, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H).

    3-(3-Chlorophenyl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile (44)

    To a vial were added (1R,5S)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile hydrochloride (203 mg, 1.40 mmol), chloro[9,9-dimethyl-4,5-bis(diphenylphosphino)xanthene] [2′-amino-1,1′biphenyl] palladium(II) (127 mg, 0.140 mmol), and K3PO4 (1.08 g, 4.91 mmol). The vial was then put under vacuum and backfilled with nitrogen. 1,4-Dioxane (3.0 mL) was added followed by 3-bromochlorobenzene (0.18 mL, 1.5 mmol), and the reaction mixture was stirred for 16 h at 110 °C. The reaction mixture was diluted with DCM and filtered through Celite, the cake was washed with DCM, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography with 0–100% isopropyl acetate in heptane to afford the title compound as an orange solid (198 mg, 64% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.12 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 6.73 (ddd, J = 8.0, 1.8, 0.8 Hz, 1H), 6.53 (t, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 6.42 (ddd, J = 8.4, 2.3, 0.8 Hz, 1H), 3.65 (d, J = 9.7 Hz, 2H), 3.41–3.23 (m, 2H), 2.40–2.30 (m, 2H), 1.45 (t, J = 3.4 Hz, 1H).

    5-(Chloromethyl)-3-(3-(3-chlorophenyl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazole (46)

    To a solution of nitrile 44 (197 mg, 0.90 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) was added hydroxylamine hydrochloride (94 mg, 1.4 mmol) followed by NaHCO3 (378 mg, 4.50 mmol), and the reaction mixture was heated to reflux overnight. Subsequently, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, filtered and the filter cake was washed with DCM. The filtrate was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was dissolved in DCM, washed with water and brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to yield crude 3-(3-chlorophenyl)-N-hydroxy-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboxamidine (210 mg, 93% yield), which was used directly in the next step.
    To a solution of 3-(3-chlorophenyl)-N-hydroxy-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboxamidine (210 mg, 0.834 mmol) in acetone (15 mL) was added chloroacetyl chloride (0.069 mL, 0.88 mmol) dropwise. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was dissolved in DCM and washed with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 and water, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to give crude (Z)-N-(2-chloroacetoxy)-3-(3-chlorophenyl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0] hexane-6-carboximidamide as a white solid (223 mg, 81% yield), which was used directly in the following step.
    To a round-bottom flask were added (Z)-N-(2-chloroacetoxy)-3-(3-chlorophenyl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboximidamide (223 mg, 0.680 mmol) and toluene (10 mL), a dean-stark apparatus was attached, and the reaction mixture was heated to 125 °C for 3 h then cooled down to room temperature. The reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo; the residue was purified by silica gel chromatography with 0–100% isopropyl acetate in heptane to afford the title compound as a light yellow oil that solidified over time (92 mg, 33% yield). LCMS, m/z = 311.1 [M + H]+.

    7-Methyl-1-[[3-[(1R,5S,6r)-3-(3-chlorophenyl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl]-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl]methyl]purin-6-one (7)

    A mixture of 7-methyl-lH-purin-6(7H)-one (44 mg, 0.28 mmol), oxadiazole 46 (91 mg, 0.29 mmol), Cs2CO3 (272 mg, 0.840 mmol), and TBAI (10 mg, 0.028 mmol) in DMF (2.0 mL) was heated to 60 °C for 2 h. The reaction was cooled to room temperature, diluted with water, and extracted with ethyl acetate (3×). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography with 10–80% isopropyl acetate/MeOH (3:1) in heptane to afford the title compound as a brown oil. The residue was then purified by RP-HPLC to yield the title compound (25.9 mg, 22% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C20H19ClN7O2 [M + H]+: 424.1283. Found: 424.1276. HPLC purity: 99.43%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.43 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.15 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 6.65 (dd, J = 7.5, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 6.56 (t, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 6.54–6.49 (m, 1H), 5.52 (s, 2H), 3.95 (s, 3H), 3.67 (d, J = 9.9 Hz, 2H), 3.30–3.25 (m, 2H), 2.23–2.18 (m, 2H), 2.01 (t, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 175.0, 170.1, 156.5, 153.5, 149.0, 147.3, 145.3, 133.7, 130.4, 115.7, 114.6, 111.8, 111.1, 49.5, 41.5, 33.4, 25.7, 17.9.

    tert-Butyl(cyclopent-3-en-1-yloxy)diphenylsilane (59)

    Into a 2000 mL three-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed cyclopent-3-en-1-ol (100 g, 1.17 mol), DMF (1000 mL), and imidazole (198 g, 2.93 mol). This was followed by the addition of TBDPSCl (376 g, 1.17 mol) dropwise with stirring at 0–5 °C over 1 h. The resulting solution was stirred for 15 h at 25 °C. A second batch of the same reaction was run in parallel. The two reaction mixtures were mixed, quenched by the addition of 10 L of water, and extracted with 3 × 1000 mL of ethyl acetate, and then the organic layers were combined. The resulting mixture was washed with 500 mL of brine and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography using petroleum ether as the eluent. This resulted in 690 g (90% yield) of the title compound as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.76–7.71 (m, 4H), 7.46–7.41 (m, 6H), 5.67 (s, 2H), 4.63–4.59 (m, 1H), 2.56–2.32 (m, 4H), 1.12 (s, 9H).

    Ethyl (1R,5S,6R)-3-[(tert-Butyldiphenylsilyl)oxy]bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboxylate (60)

    Into a 3000 mL three-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed DCM (1.5 L), silyl ether 59 (173 g, 535 mmol), and Rh2(OAc)4 (2.83 g, 6.34 mmol). This was followed by the addition of a solution of ethyl 2-diazoacetate (134 g, 1.18 mol) in DCM (1.5 L) dropwise with stirring at 25 °C over 8 h. The resulting solution was stirred overnight at 25 °C. The reaction was repeated three times. The resulting mixture was concentrated in vacuo. This resulted in 864 g (crude) of the title compound as a yellow oil. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.78–7.55 (m, 4H), 7.57–7.30 (m, 6H), 4.28 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 4.14 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 1H), 3.90–3.87 (m, 1H), 2.25–1.76 (m, 4H), 1.42–1.16 (m, 5H), 1.10–1.01 (m, 9H).

    (1R,5S,6R)-3-[(tert-Butyldiphenylsilyl)oxy]bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboxylic Acid (61)

    Into a 10 L four-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed ester 60 (860 g, 2.10 mol) and ethanol (3.0 L). This was followed by the addition of 5 N sodium hydroxide (2.92 L, 14.6 mol) dropwise with stirring at 15 °C over 2 h. The resulting solution was stirred for 24 h at 25 °C. The resulting mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The pH value of the solution was adjusted to 3–4 with HCl (4 N). The solid was collected by filtration and dried in an oven under reduced pressure. This resulted in 400 g (50% yield) of the title compound as an off-white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.92 (s, 1H), 7.62–7.52 (m, 4H), 7.49–7.38 (m, 6H), 4.28 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 1.99–1.96 (m, 3H), 1.85–1.69 (m, 4H), 1.01 (s, 9H).

    (1R,5S,6S)-3-[(tert-Butyldiphenylsilyl)oxy]bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboxamide (62)

    Into a 10 L four-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed carboxylic acid 61 (400 g, 1.05 mol) and DMF (4.0 L). This was followed by the addition of HATU (600 g, 1.58 mol) at 10 °C. To this was added DIPEA (408 g, 3.15 mol) at 15 °C, and the resulting solution was stirred for 30 min at 25 °C. To the mixture was added NH4Cl (169 g, 3.16 mol) portion-wise with stirring at 15 °C. The resulting solution was stirred for 3 h at 25 °C and then diluted with 8 L of water. The solids were collected by filtration and dried in an oven under reduced pressure. This resulted in 370 g (93% yield) of the title compound as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.83–7.58 (m, 4H), 7.44–7.42 (m, 6H), 5.53 (s, 1H), 5.37 (s, 1H), 3.89 (p, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 2.13–1.71 (m, 6H), 1.07 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 9H), 0.89 (t, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H).

    (1R,5S,6S)-3-[(tert-Butyldiphenylsilyl)oxy]bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile (63)

    Into a 5 L four-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed 1,4-dioxane (3.5 L), amide 62 (370 g, 975 mmol), and pyridine (200 g, 2.53 mol). This was followed by the dropwise addition of TFAA (266 g, 1.27 mol), stirring at 15 °C over 1 h. The resulting solution was stirred for 4 h at 25 °C and then diluted with 2.5 L of saturated aqueous NaHCO3 and 2.5 L of H2O. The resulting solution was extracted with 3 × 1 L of DCM, and the organic layers were combined and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography with ethyl acetate/petroleum ether (1:4). This resulted in 300 g (85% yield) of the title compound as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.81–7.54 (m, 4H), 7.54–7.30 (m, 6H), 4.65–3.64 (m, 1H), 2.34–1.80 (m, 5H), 1.78–1.22 (m, 1H), 1.21–0.98 (m, 9H), 0.98–0.56 (m, 1H).

    (1R,5S,6S)-3-Hydroxybicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile (64)

    Into a 5 L four-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed tetrahydrofuran (3.0 L) and nitrile 63 (300 g, 830 mmol). This was followed by the addition of a solution of TBAF (1 M in THF, 1.25 L, 1.25 mol) dropwise with stirring at 15 °C over 2 h. The resulting solution was stirred for 14 h at 25 °C in a water bath. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of 3.0 L of saturated aqueous NH4Cl and 2.0 L of H2O. The resulting solution was extracted with 3 × 1 L of ethyl acetate, and the organic layers were combined and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography with ethyl acetate/petroleum ether (2:3). This resulted in 86 g (84% yield) of the title compound as a yellow oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 4.41–3.83 (m, 1H), 2.34–2.19 (m, 1H), 2.18–2.05 (m, 1H), 2.04–1.86 (m, 3H), 1.88–1.71 (m, 1H), 1.70–0.92 (m, 1H).

    (1R,5S,6S)-3-Oxobicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile (65)

    Into a 10 L four-necked round-bottom flask purged and maintained with an inert atmosphere of nitrogen were placed alcohol 64 (86 g, 700 mmol) and DCM (6.0 L). DMP (370 g, 872 mmol) was then added in portions at 0–5 °C over 2 h. The resulting solution was stirred at 0–5 °C in an ice/water bath for 2 h. The solution was stirred for an additional 12 h, while the temperature was maintained at 25 °C in a water bath. The reaction was then quenched by the addition of 1 L of saturated aqueous Na2SO3. The resulting solution was further diluted with 1 L of water. The pH value of the solution was adjusted to 7 with saturated aqueous NaHCO3. The resulting solution was extracted with 3 × 1 L of DCM, and the organic layers were combined and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography with ethyl acetate/petroleum ether (1:2). This resulted in 55 g (65% yield) of the title compound as an off-white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 2.72–2.69 (m, 2H), 2.43–2.22 (m, 4H), 1.02 (t, J = 3.5 Hz, 1H).

    (1R,5S,6R)-3-Hydroxy-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile (66)

    To a solution of ketone 65 (115 mg, 0.950 mmol) in THF (9.5 mL) was added a 0.6 M solution of lanthanum(III) chloride bis(lithium chloride) complex in THF (1.9 mL, 1.1 mmol) at room temperature. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature, and it was then cooled to −78 °C. A 2 M solution of phenylmagnesium chloride in THF (0.57 mL, 1.1 mmol) was added dropwise, and the reaction mixture was stirred at −78 °C for 15 min. The reaction mixture was warmed to 0 °C and stirred for 1 h at that temperature. A saturated aqueous solution of NH4Cl was added, and the mixture was extracted with Et2O (3 × 50 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to afford the title compound (144 mg, 76% yield) as an off-white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.40–7.31 (m, 5H), 2.51–2.44 (m, 2H), 2.33 (t, J = 3.4 Hz, 1H), 2.29–2.23 (m, 2H), 2.15–2.09 (m, 2H), 1.55 (s, 1H).

    rac-(1R,5R,6S)-3-Phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hex-2-ene-6-carbonitrile (67)

    To a solution of alcohol 66 (658 mg, 3.30 mmol) in DCM (17 mL) was added trifluoroacetic acid (1.30 mL, 16.5 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15 min, and the reaction mixture was diluted with toluene (20 mL). Volatiles were removed in vacuo. The obtained residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (ethyl acetate in hexanes, 0–15% gradient) to afford the title compound (461 mg, 77% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.36–7.29 (m, 4H), 7.28–7.24 (m, 1H), 6.30 (q, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 3.16 (ddd, J = 17.8, 6.9, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 2.89 (dt, J = 4.3, 2.4 Hz, 1H), 2.71–2.60 (m, 1H), 2.39 (td, J = 6.6, 3.7 Hz, 1H), 0.94 (t, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H).

    (1R,5S,6R)-3-Phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile (68)

    In a 10 mL round-bottom flask were added alkene 67 (70 mg, 0.39 mmol), 10% palladium on carbon (15 mg), and EtOH (3.9 mL). The flask was mounted with a vacuum/hydrogen balloon adaptor. The flask was vacuumed and back-filled with hydrogen three times, and the mixture was allowed to stir at room temperature for 3 h. The reaction mixture was filtered on Celite, the cake was rinsed with DCM and MeOH, and the solvent was evaporated to give crude title compound (62 mg, 88% yield) as a mixture of diastereomers. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): major stereoisomer: 7.33–7.27 (m, 2H), 7.22–7.15 (m, 1H), 7.15–7.11 (m, 2H), 3.61–3.52 (m, 1H), 2.53–2.45 (m, 2H), 2.12–2.04 (m, 4H), 1.16 (t, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H).

    5-(Chloromethyl)-3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazole (70)

    To a solution of nitrile 68 (62 mg, 0.31 mmol) in methanol (1.3 mL) were added hydroxylamine hydrochloride (39 mg, 0.57 mmol) and NaHCO3 (132 mg, 1.57 mmol). The mixture was heated at 65 °C for 20 h. The solvent was evaporated, and the obtained residue was diluted with water and DCM. The phases were separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with DCM (2 × 30 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to give crude (1R,5S,6R)-N′-hydroxy-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboximidamide (67 mg, 99% yield) as a mixture of diastereomers.
    To a 0 °C solution of chloroacetyl chloride (0.025 mL, 0.31 mmol) in DCM (3.1 mL) was added crude (1R,5S,6R)-N′-hydroxy-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboximidamide (67 mg, 0.31 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 45 min. A saturated aqueous solution of NaHCO3 was added, and the mixture was extracted with DCM (3 × 25 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to give crude (1R,5S,6R)-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboximidamide (90 mg, 99% yield) as a brown oil (mixture of diastereomers).
    A solution of crude (1R,5S,6R)-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboximidamide (91 mg, 0.31 mmol) in toluene (7 mL) was refluxed for 3 h. The solvent was evaporated to give crude title compound (85 mg, 99% yield) as a brown solid, which was used directly in the next step.

    7-Methyl-1-((3-((1R,3R,5S,6R)-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-1H-purin-6(7H)-one (8)

    Oxadiazole 70 (85 mg, 0.31 mmol), TBAI (11 mg, 0.030 mmol), and K2CO3 (128 mg, 0.930 mmol) were charged in a 10 mL round-bottom flask under nitrogen. DMF (1.5 mL) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred at 20 °C for 1.5 h. A saturated aqueous solution of NaHCO3 and water was added, and the mixture was extracted with DCM (3 × 25 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (MeOH in DCM, 0–8% gradient) to afford the title compound (25 mg, 21% yield) as a mixture of diastereomers. The product was purified by semi-prep HPLC (conditions: ChiralPak IA, 5 mm, 20 × 250 mm, 10:15:75 (MeOH/DCM/hexane), 12 mL/min, 3 injections of 5–10 mg/injection, 5 mg/mL). The obtained product (first diastereomer to come out) was triturated in ethyl acetate and dissolved in a solution of MeCN and water. The solution was frozen and lyophilized to give the title compound (10 mg, 8% yield) as a white solid. Relative stereochemistry of the compound was confirmed by NOESY NMR. LCMS, m/z = 389.0 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.41 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.31–7.21 (m, 4H), 7.19–7.10 (m, 1H), 5.47 (s, 2H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 3.61–3.49 (m, 1H), 2.48–2.42 (m, 2H), 1.94–1.84 (m, 5H). 13C NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3) δ 172.8, 171.5, 157.0, 153.9, 146.0, 144.9, 144.3, 128.5, 127.1, 126.0, 115.5, 47.0, 40.8, 36.2, 33.9, 29.9, 23.4.

    (rac)-5-(Chloromethyl)-3-((1S,5S,6R)-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hex-2-en-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazole (69)

    A solution of alkene 67 (461 mg, 2.54 mmol) in EtOH (17 mL) was heated at 80 °C, and hydroxylamine (0.78 mL, 13 mmol) was added in one portion. The reaction mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. The solvent was then evaporated in vacuo and the residue was further co-evaporated with EtOH (2 × 10 mL) to give 545 mg of rac-(1S,5S,6R)-N′-hydroxy-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hex-2-ene-6-carboximidamide as a yellowish solid.
    Pivalic acid (2.9 mL, 25 mmol) was added to a solution of rac-(1S,5S,6R)-N′-hydroxy-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hex-2-ene-6-carboximidamide (545 mg, 2.54 mmol) in DCE (13 mL). Chloroacetic anhydride (696 mg, 4.07 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 40 min. Ethyl acetate (75 mL) was added, and the solution was slowly transferred to a saturated aqueous solution of NaHCO3 (125 mL). The phases were separated and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (2 × 50 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (ethyl acetate in hexanes, 5–15% gradient) to afford the title compound (461 mg, 66% yield) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.40–7.37 (m, 2H), 7.33–7.29 (m, 2H), 7.26–7.22 (m, 1H), 6.42 (q, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 4.63 (s, 2H), 3.20 (ddd, J = 17.6, 6.9, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 2.95 (dt, J = 17.6, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 2.59 (dq, J = 6.8, 2.3 Hz, 1H), 2.39 (td, J = 6.7, 3.5 Hz, 1H), 1.74 (dd, J = 3.4, 2.5 Hz, 1H).

    7-Methyl-1-((3-((1S,5S,6R)-3-phenylbicyclo[3.1.0]hex-2-en-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-1,7-dihydro-6H-purin-6-one (9)

    In a 50 mL round-bottom flask were charged 7-methyl-lH-purin-6-one (381 mg, 2.54 mmol), oxadiazole 69 (461 mg, 1.69 mmol), TBAI (62 mg, 0.17 mmol), K2CO3 (701 mg, 5.07 mmol), and DMF (11 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 20 °C for 1.5 h and then diluted with H2O (80 mL). The formed solid was collected by filtration and washed with water (25 mL). The obtained material was purified by silica gel chromatography using MeOH in DCM (1–8% gradient) as eluent to afford a racemic mixture of the desired products (477 mg, 73% yield) as a white solid. The racemic material was separated by SFC with the following conditions: column OJ, 10 × 250 mm, 5 μm, isocratic 40% MeCN + EtOH 1:1, 10 mL/min, 100 bar, column temperature: 35 °C, run time: 11 min. The desired enantiomer was isolated as a white solid (194 mg, 30% yield), Rt = 9.5 min (OJ, 10 × 250 mm, 5 μm, isocratic 40% MeCN + EtOH 1:1, 10 mL/min, 100 bar). HRMS m/z calcd for C21H19N6O2 [M + H]+: 387.1564. Found: 387.1556. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.43 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.46–7.37 (m, 2H), 7.31 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 7.27–7.19 (m, 1H), 6.53 (q, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 5.51 (s, 2H), 3.95 (s, 3H), 3.09 (ddd, J = 17.8, 6.8, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 2.91 (d, J = 17.8 Hz, 1H), 2.47–2.43 (m, 1H), 2.26 (td, J = 6.6, 3.4 Hz, 1H), 1.64 (t, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 175.3, 170.7, 157.0, 154.0, 147.8, 145.8, 142.6, 135.7, 128.9, 127.9, 127.1, 125.9, 115.1, 42.0, 36.6, 34.8, 33.9, 25.8, 24.8.

    (1R,5S,6R)-3-(4-Chloropyridin-2-yl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile (45)

    To a vial were added 3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carbonitrile hydrochloride (2.00 g, 13.8 mmol), 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (10.6 mL, 69.2 mmol), pyridine (50 mL), and 4-chloro-2-fluoropyridine (4.10 mL, 41.5 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at 110 °C for 16 h. The reaction mixture was washed with water, extracted three times with isopropyl acetate, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography, eluting with 0–100% isopropyl acetate in heptane to afford the title compound as a white solid (2.27 g, 75% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.02 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 6.68 (dd, J = 5.4, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 6.55 (d, J = 1.6 Hz, 1H), 3.77 (d, J = 11.0 Hz, 2H), 3.41–3.36 (m, 2H), 2.46–2.41 2H), l.66 (t, J = 3.5 Hz, 1H).

    5-(Chloromethyl)-3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-(4-chloropyridin-2-yl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazole (47)

    To a solution of nitrile 45 (3.58 g, 16.3 mmol) in ethanol (109 mL) was added hydroxylamine (50 mass % in H2O, 5.0 mL, 81.5 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. The solvent was then evaporated in vacuo and the residue was further co-evaporated with EtOH (2 × 10 mL) to give crude 3-(4-chloro-2-pyridyl)-N′-hydroxy-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboxamidine. Pivalic acid (18.9 mL, 163 mmol) was added to a solution of the crude material in DCE (81.5 mL). Chloroacetic anhydride (4.51 g, 26.1 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 40 min. Isopropyl acetate (75 mL) was added, and the solution was slowly transferred to a saturated aqueous solution of NaHCO3 (125 mL). The phases were separated and the aqueous layer was extracted with isopropyl acetate (2 × 50 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (isopropyl acetate in heptane, 0–100% gradient) to afford the title compound (4.55 g, 90% yield) as a yellow oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.04 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 6.68 (dd, J = 5.4, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 6.57 (d, J = 1.7 Hz, 1H), 5.05 (s, 2H), 3.85 (d, J = 10.8 Hz, 2H), 3.49 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 2H), 2.31–2.22 (m, 2H), 2.03 (t, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H).

    1-((3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-(4-Chloropyridin-2-yl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-7-methyl-1,7-dihydro-6H-purin-6-one (10)

    A mixture of oxadiazole 47 (4.55 g, 14.6 mmol), 7-methyl-1,7-dihydro-6H-purin-6-one (2.41 g, 16.1 mmol), Cs2CO3 (14.3 g, 43.8 mmol), and TBAI (540 mg, 1.46 mmol) in DMF (146 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 30 min. The reaction was cooled to room temperature, diluted with water, and extracted with ethyl acetate (3×). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (MeOH in DCM, 0–10% gradient) to afford the title compound as a white solid (3.14 g, 51% yield). HRMS m/z calcd for C19H18ClN8O2 [M + H]+: 425.1236. Found: 425.1227. HPLC purity: 100.00%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.43 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 8.02 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 6.67 (dd, J = 5.4, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 6.55 (d, J = 1.7 Hz, 1H), 5.52 (s, 2H), 3.95 (s, 3H), 3.81 (d, J = 10.8 Hz, 2H), 3.46 (dt, J = 11.1, 1.8 Hz, 2H), 2.24–2.14 (m, 2H), 1.97 (t, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 175.0, 170.0, 158.2, 156.5, 153.5, 149.2, 147.3, 145.3, 143.2, 114.6, 112.0, 106.2, 48.7, 41.5, 33.4, 25.6, 18.1.

    3-((3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-(4-Chloropyridin-2-yl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidin-4(3H)-one (11)

    Oxadiazole 47 (220 mg, 0.710 mmol) and pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidin-4(3H)-one (155 mg, 1.05 mmol) were mixed in DMF (3.5 mL). K2CO3 (292 mg, 2.11 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 h. H2O and DMF were added to the reaction mixture for purification by reverse-phase chromatography using a 60 g C18 column, eluting with 0–100% MeCN/10 mM ammonium bicarbonate (pH 10). Fractions were combined, frozen, and lyophilized to give 225 mg of a yellow solid. This product was purified again by reverse-phase chromatography using a 60 g C18 column, eluting with 0–60% MeCN/10 mM ammonium bicarbonate (pH 10). Fractions were combined, frozen, and lyophilized to give 147 mg of a white solid. This product was purified by silica gel chromatography (MeOH in DCM, 0–10% gradient). The obtained product was purified by SFC (conditions: Lux Cel-3, 10 × 250 mm, 5 μm, 60% MeOH, 10 mL/min, 150 bar, column temp: 40 °C, run time: 7 min). The product was dissolved in a mixture of MeCN and water, frozen, and lyophilized to give the title compound (second eluting stereoisomer, 84 mg, 28% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C20H17ClN7O2 [M + H]+: 422.1127. Found: 422.1116. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.01 (dd, J = 4.6, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 8.73 (s, 1H), 8.54 (dd, J = 7.9, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 8.00 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (dd, J = 7.9, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 6.64 (dd, J = 5.4, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 6.52 (d, J = 1.7 Hz, 1H), 5.52 (s, 2H), 3.82–3.75 (m, 2H), 3.46–3.39 (m, 2H), 2.20–2.14 (m, 2H), 1.96 (t, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 175.1, 170.5, 161.0, 158.6, 158.3, 156.8, 151.2, 149.7, 143.6, 136.5, 123.7, 117.1, 112.5, 106.6, 49.1, 42.6, 26.1, 18.5.

    tert-Butyl (1R,5S,6R)-6-Carbamoyl-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate (49)

    To a 100 mL round-bottom flask were added (1S,5R)-3-tert-butoxycarbonyl-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-6-carboxylic acid (2.00 g, 8.80 mmol), 1-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (2.04 g, 10.6 mmol), 1-hydroxybenzotriazole (1.43 g, 10.6 mmol), and DCM (24 mL). DIPEA (1.86 mL, 10.6 mmol) was added dropwise, and the reaction was then cooled to 0 °C. A 2.0 M solution of NH3 in MeOH (19.9 mL, 39.8 mmol) was added to the solution dropwise, and the reaction was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. The reaction was diluted with DCM, washed with brine, extracted with DCM (3×), dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (10% MeOH in DCM) to afford the title compound as a white crystalline solid (1.56 g, 78% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 5.61 (s, 1H), 5.30 (s, 1H), 3.71–3.56 (m, 2H), 3.43 (d, J = 11.1 Hz, 2H), 2.08 (t, J = 2.5 Hz, 2H), 1.44 (s, 9H), 1.28 (t, J = 3.1 Hz, 1H).

    tert-Butyl (1R,5S,6R)-6-Cyano-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate (50)

    To a 50 mL round-bottom flask were added amide 49 (1.00 g, 4.42 mmol) and cyanuric acid (815 mg, 4.42 mmol) in DMF (17 mL). The reaction was stirred for 2 h at room temperature.
