The reaction was diluted with water and extracted three times with isopropyl acetate. The organic layers were combined, washed two times with water and then brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo to afford the title compound as a clear yellow oil, which crystallized over time (879 mg, 96% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 3.76–3.58 (m, 2H), 3.39 (d, J = 11.5 Hz, 2H), 2.16 (t, J = 2.5 Hz, 2H), 1.43 (s, 9H), 1.24 (t, J = 3.5 Hz, 1H).

    tert-Butyl (1R,5S,6R)-6-(5-(Chloromethyl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-3-yl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate (51)

    To a solution of nitrile 50 (500 mg, 2.4 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL) was added hydroxylamine hydrochloride (250 mg, 3.6 mmol) followed by NaHCO3 (1.0 g, 12.0 mmol), and the reaction mixture was heated to reflux overnight. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered, and the filter cake was further washed with DCM, after which the filtrate was then concentrated in vacuo. The resulting residue was dissolved in DCM and washed with water, brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to yield crude tert-butyl 6-[(Z)-N′-hydroxycarbamimidoyl]-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate (559 mg, 96% yield).
    To a solution of tert-butyl 6-[(Z)-N′-hydroxycarbamimidoyl]-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate (559 mg, 2.3 mmol) in acetone (15 mL) was added chloroacetyl chloride (0.19 mL, 2.4 mmol) slowly, dropwise. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The reaction mixture was then concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was dissolved in DCM and washed with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 and water, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to afford tert-butyl (1R,5S,6R)-6-((Z)-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)carbamimidoyl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate as a white foam (468 mg, 64% yield).
    To a round-bottom flask was added tert-butyl (1R,5S,6R)-6-((Z)-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)carbamimidoyl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate (468 mg, 1.5 mmol) followed by toluene (20 mL), a dean-stark apparatus was attached, and the mixture was heated to 125 °C for 3 h then cooled to room temperature. The reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 0–100% ethyl acetate in heptane to afford the title compound as a light yellow oil that solidified over time (376 mg, 85% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 4.61 (s, 2H), 3.79 (d, J = 11.2 Hz, 1H), 3.70 (d, J = 11.1 Hz, 1H), 3.53–3.43 (m, 2H), 2.20–2.08 (m, 2H), 1.97 (t, J = 3.4 Hz, 1H), 1.46 (s, 9H).

    tert-Butyl (1R,5S,6R)-6-(5-((5-Oxopyrido[2,3-d]pyridazin-6(5H)yl)methyl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-3-yl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate (52)

    A mixture of pyrido[2,3-d]pyridazin-5(6H)-one (426 mg, 2.75 mmol), oxadiazole 51 (750 mg, 2.50 mmol), Cs2CO3 (2.45 g, 7.51 mmol), and TBAI (46 mg, 0.13 mmol) in DMF (25.0 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 3 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with water and extracted with ethyl acetate (3×). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 10–80% isopropyl acetate/MeOH (3:1) in heptane to afford the title compound as a beige solid (969 mg, 94% yield). LCMS, m/z = 411.2 [M + H]+.

    6-((3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-(4-Chloropyridin-2-yl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)pyrido[2,3-d]pyridazin-5(6H)-one (12)

    To a solution of carbamate 52 (969 mg, 2.36 mmol) in DCM (10 mL) was added 4 M HCl in 1,4-dioxane (5.9 mL, 24 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h then concentrated in vacuo to give crude 6-((3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)pyrido[2,3-d]pyridazin-5-one hydrochloride as a beige solid (818 mg, 99% yield). The residue was used directly in the next step without further purification.
    To a sealable tube were added 6-((3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)pyrido[2,3-d]pyridazin-5-one hydrochloride (200 mg, 0.58 mmol), K3PO4 (625 mg, 2.88 mmol), 4-chloro-2-fluoropyridine (0.18 mL, 1.7 mmol), and 1,4-dioxane (2.5 mL). The vial was sealed, and the reaction mixture was stirred at 110 °C for 18 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with DCM and filtered through Celite, the filter cake was washed with DCM, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 10–80% isopropyl acetate/MeOH (3:1) in heptane to afford the partially purified desired compound as an orange solid. The product was further purified by achiral SFC to yield the title compound (81 mg, 33% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C20H17ClN7O2 [M + H]+: 422.1127. Found: 422.1121. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.21 (dd, J = 4.6, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 8.65 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 8.60 (s, 1H), 8.03 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 7.93 (dd, J = 8.1, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 6.67 (dd, J = 5.5, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 6.55 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 5.67 (s, 2H), 3.82 (d, J = 10.9 Hz, 2H), 3.47 (dt, J = 11.0, 1.9 Hz, 2H), 2.23–2.19 (m, 2H), 1.99 (t, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 175.2, 170.5, 159.0, 158.6, 156.9, 149.7, 146.4, 143.6, 140.7, 135.0, 127.7, 123.9, 112.5, 106.6, 49.2, 47.4, 26.0, 18.6.

    tert-Butyl (1R,5S,6R)-6-(5-((5-Methyl-4-oxoimidazo[1,5-f][1,2,4]triazin-3(4H)-yl)methyl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-3-yl)-3-aza-bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane-3-carboxylate (53)

    A mixture of oxadiazole 51 (240 mg, 0.800 mmol), 5-methyl-3H-imidazo[5,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-4-one (120 mg, 0.800 mmol), TBAI (30 mg, 0.080 mmol), and K2CO3 (332 mg, 2.40 mmol) in DMF (10 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The residue was purified by RP-HPLC to afford the title compound (150 mg, 45% yield) as a white solid. LCMS, m/z = 414.2 [M + H]+.

    3-((3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-(4-Chloropyridin-2-yl)-3-aza-bicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-5-methylimidazo[1,5-f][1,2,4]triazin-4(3H)-one (13)

    A solution of carbamate 53 (150 mg, 0.360 mmol) and 4 M HCl in 1,4-dioxane (5 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The solvent was concentrated in vacuo to afford crude 3-((3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-aza-bicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-5-methylimidazo[1,5-f][1,2,4]triazin-4(3H)-one hydrochloride (120 mg, 95% yield) as a white solid. To 100 mg (0.290 mmol) of this intermediate were added 4-chloro-2-fluoropyridine (56 mg, 0.43 mmol), DIPEA (111 mg, 0.90 mmol), and DMF (2 mL), and the mixture was stirred at 100 °C overnight. The resulting solution was purified by RP-HPLC to yield the title compound (58 mg, 48% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C19H18ClN8O2 [M + H]+: 425.1236. Found: 425.1230. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.39 (s, 1H), 8.21 (s, 1H), 8.02 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1H), 6.66 (dd, J = 5.6, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 6.54 (d, J = 1.2 Hz, 1H), 5.35 (s, 2H), 3.83 (d, J = 10.8 Hz, 2H), 3.45 (d, J = 10.8 Hz, 2H), 2.47 (s, 3H), 2.21 (s, 2H), 1.98 (t, J = 3.2 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 175.1, 170.5, 158.6, 154.1, 149.7, 143.7, 142.9, 140.4, 133.9, 114.8, 112.5, 106.6, 49.2, 41.0, 26.1, 18.5, 14.8.

    3-((3-((1R,5S,6R)-3-(4-Chloropyridin-2-yl)-3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexan-6-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-5-methylpyrazolo[5,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-4(3H)-one (14)

    In a flask containing oxadiazole 47 (375 mg, 1.21 mmol), 5-methyl-3H-pyrazolo[5,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-4-one (235 mg, 1.57 mmol) and K2CO3 (500 mg, 3.62 mmol) was added DMF (6.0 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 20 °C for 2 h. Water was added, and the mixture was sonicated and stirred vigorously to form a white suspension. The solid was filtered and washed with water. The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (ethyl acetate in hexanes, 25–100% gradient) to afford the title compound (425 mg) as a white solid. The compound was further purified by recrystallization in absolute EtOH and water to provide the title compound (322 mg, 63% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C19H18ClN8O2 [M + H]+: 425.1236. Found: 425.1229. HPLC purity: 100.00%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.39 (s, 1H), 8.02 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 7.76 (s, 1H), 6.67 (dd, J = 5.4, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 6.55 (d, J = 1.7 Hz, 1H), 5.43 (s, 2H), 3.82 (d, J = 10.9 Hz, 2H), 3.50–3.39 (m, 2H), 2.35 (s, 3H), 2.24–2.18 (m, 2H), 1.99 (t, J = 3.2 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 174.4, 170.0, 158.2, 154.0, 149.2, 143.2, 140.7, 138.4, 124.3, 116.7, 112.0, 106.2, 48.7, 40.9, 25.6, 18.0, 9.1.
    3-(2-(3-Chlorophenoxy)ethyl)-5-((7-methyl-6-oxo-6H-purin-1(7H)-6l)methyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2(3H)-one (15)
    A mixture of alkyl bromide 71 (95 mg, 0.403 mmol), oxadiazolone 34 (101 mg, 0.407 mmol), K2CO3 (112 mg, 0.810 mmol), TBAI (15 mg, 0.041 mmol), and DMF (4 mL) was stirred for 3 h at room temperature. The solids were filtered out, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was purified by RP-HPLC to afford the title compound (39 mg, 24% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C17H16ClN6O4 [M + H]+: 403.0916. Found: 403.0905. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.35 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.28 (t, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 7.04–6.97 (m, 2H), 6.91–6.83 (m, 1H), 5.23 (s, 2H), 4.23 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 2H), 4.04–3.93 (m, 5H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 159.3, 156.8, 153.9, 153.5, 152.0, 147.6, 145.7, 134.2, 131.4, 121.5, 115.2, 115.1, 114.2, 65.3, 45.3, 40.8, 33.9.

    1-((4-(3-(3-Chlorophenoxy)propyl)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl)methyl)-7-methyl-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-6-one (16)

    A mixture of oxadiazolone 34 (50 mg, 0.20 mmol), TBAI (7.4 mg, 0.020 mmol), K2CO3 (84 mg, 0.60 mmol), and alkyl bromide 72 (50 mg, 0.20 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) was stirred for 2 h at 25 °C. The solids were filtered out, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by RP-HPLC to afford the title compound (51 mg, 61% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C18H18ClN6O4 [M + H]+: 417.1073. Found: 417.1064. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.34 (s, 1H), 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.27 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.99–6.95 (m, 2H), 6.86–6.84 (m, 1H), 5.22 (s, 2H), 4.03 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 3.96 (s, 3H), 3.80 (t, J = 6.7 Hz, 2H), 2.08–2.01 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 159.8, 156.8, 153.9, 153.4, 151.8, 147.6, 145.7, 134.2, 131.3, 121.1, 115.1, 114.9, 114.0, 65.6, 43.0, 40.7, 33.9, 27.6.

    (1R,3R)-3-(Benzyloxy)cyclobutanol (74)

    Sodium borohydride (215 mg, 5.68 mmol) was added to a solution of 3-benzyloxycyclobutanone (1.00 g, 5.68 mmol) in methanol (19 mL). The reaction was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. The reaction was quenched with water and was extracted with isopropyl acetate (3×). The combined organic extracts were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude mixture was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 0–80% isopropyl acetate in heptane to afford the title compound (880 mg, 87% yield) as a clear oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.39–7.26 (m, 5H), 4.42 (s, 2H), 3.92 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 1H), 3.69–3.57 (m, 1H), 2.72 (dtd, J = 9.5, 6.6, 3.0 Hz, 2H), 2.01–1.87 (m, 2H), 1.66 (d, J = 6.2 Hz, 1H).

    (1R,3R)-3-(Benzyloxy)cyclobutyl 4-Methylbenzenesulfonate (75)

    DIAD (1.69 mL, 8.53 mmol) was added to a solution of 3-(benzyloxy)cyclobutanol (800 mg, 4.26 mmol), pyridinium p-toluenesulfonate (2.14 g, 8.53 mmol), and triphenylphosphine (2.24 g, 8.53 mmol) in THF (43 mL). The mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 2 days. The crude mixture was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 0–50% isopropyl acetate in heptane to afford the title compound (1.25 g, 88% yield) as a clear oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.81–7.74 (m, 2H), 7.38–7.27 (m, 7H), 5.07–4.92 (m, 1H), 4.36 (s, 2H), 4.22 (tt, J = 6.6, 4.4 Hz, 1H), 2.45 (s, 3H), 2.43–2.30 (m, 4H).

    (1R,3R)-3-Hydroxycyclobutyl 4-Methylbenzenesulfonate (76)

    A mixture of 3-(benzyloxy)cyclobutyl 4-methylbenzenesulfonate (1.11 g, 3.34 mmol) and Pd on carbon (10% wt) (533 mg, 0.50 mmol) in EtOH (33 mL) under N2 was backfilled with H2 (3×) using a balloon and stirred overnight. The reaction mixture was filtered through diatomaceous earth, and the cake was washed with MeOH. The filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The crude mixture was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 30–100% isopropyl acetate in heptane to afford the title compound (597 mg, 74% yield) as a clear oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.83–7.73 (m, 2H), 7.37–7.31 (m, 2H), 5.02 (tt, J = 7.0, 4.7 Hz, 1H), 4.54 (tt, J = 7.0, 4.0 Hz, 1H), 2.53–2.39 (m, 5H), 2.33–2.19 (m, 2H), 1.62 (br, 1H).

    (1S,3S)-3-(5-((7-Methyl-6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl)methyl)-2-oxo-1,3,4-oxadiazol-3(2H)-yl)cyclobutyl 4-Methyl Benzenesulfonate (77)

    DIAD (449 μL, 2.27 mmol) was added to a solution of oxadiazolone 34 (375 mg, 1.51 mmol), 3-hydroxycyclobutyl 4-methylbenzenesulfonate (476 mg, 1.96 mmol), and triphenylphosphine (594 mg, 2.27 mmol) in THF (10 mL) at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The same amounts of DIAD and triphenylphosphine were added, and the reaction was stirred at 50 °C for 7 h. The crude mixture was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 30–80% isopropyl acetate/MeOH (3:1) in heptane to afford the title compound (547 mg, 77% yield) as a white solid. LCMS, m/z = 473.1 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.04 (s, 1H), 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.81–7.76 (m, 2H), 7.35 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 5.10 (s, 2H), 4.58 (p, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 4.21–4.11 (m, 1H), 4.10 (s, 3H), 2.74–2.59 (m, 4H), 2.46 (s, 3H).

    trans-3-[3-(3-Chlorophenoxy)cyclobutyl]-5-[(7-methyl-6-oxopurin-1-yl)methyl]-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-one (17)

    A mixture of cyclobutane 77 (100 mg, 0.212 mmol), 3-chlorophenol (44 μL, 0.42 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (138 mg, 0.424 mmol) in DMSO (1.1 mL) was stirred at 80 °C overnight. The reaction mixture was partitioned in water/isopropyl acetate and extracted with isopropyl acetate (3×). The combined organic extracts were washed with brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude mixture was purified by silica gel chromatography with 30–80% isopropyl acetate/MeOH (3:1) in heptane. The compound was further purified by chiral SFC using a Chiralpak OJ column with 40% of the 0.1% ammonium hydroxide in MeOH in CO2. This resulted in the title compound (10.9 mg, 12% yield) as a white solid. LCMS, m/z = 429.1 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.36 (s, 1H), 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.30 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.00 (ddd, J = 8.0, 2.0, 0.9 Hz, 1H), 6.89 (t, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 6.81 (ddd, J = 8.4, 2.5, 0.9 Hz, 1H), 5.26 (s, 2H), 4.90 (tt, J = 7.0, 3.6 Hz, 1H), 4.69 (tt, J = 8.5, 6.2 Hz, 1H), 3.97 (s, 3H), 2.85–2.74 (m, 2H), 2.58–2.50 (m, 2H).

    3-(tert-Butyldimethylsilyloxy)cyclopentanol (79)

    To tert-butyldimethylchlorosilane (1.33 g, 8.81 mmol) were added trans-1,3-cyclopentanediol (1.00 g, 9.79 mmol) and imidazole (0.800 g, 11.8 mmol) in THF (10 mL) at 0 °C. The resulting solution was stirred for 12 h at room temperature. The reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (1:1) to afford the title compound (1.3 g, 61% yield) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 4.48–4.39 (m, 2H), 2.19–1.97 (m, 2H), 1.91–1.77 (m, 2H), 1.64–1.45 (m, 2H), 0.89 (s, 9H), 0.06 (s, 6H).

    tert-Butyl(3-(3-fluorophenoxy)cyclopentyloxy)dimethylsilane (80)

    DIAD (1.82 g, 9.01 mmol) was added dropwise to the solution of 3-fluorophenol (750 mg, 6.61 mmol), alcohol 79 (1.30 g, 6.01 mmol), and triphenylphosphine (4.72 g, 18.0 mmol) in THF (15 mL) at 0 °C. The resulting solution was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with DCM/MeOH (20:1) to afford the title compound (800 mg, 43% yield) as a colorless oil.

    3-(3-Fluorophenoxy)cyclopentanol (81)

    A solution of silyl ether 80 (800 mg, 2.58 mmol) and TBAF (1.35 g, 5.15 mmol) in THF (20 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The solvent was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (2:1) to afford the title compound (450 mg, 89% yield) as a colorless oil.

    3-((1S,3S)-3-(3-Fluorophenoxy)cyclopentyl)-5-((7-methyl-6-oxo-6H-purin-1(7H)-yl)methyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2(3H)-one (18)

    DIAD (154 mg, 0.760 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of cyclopentanol 81 (100 mg, 0.510 mmol), oxadiazolone 34 (127 mg, 0.510 mmol), and triphenylphosphine (401 mg, 1.53 mmol) in THF (10 mL) at 0 °C. The resulting solution was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with DCM/MeOH (4:1) to afford the racemate. The product was then separated by Chiral-Prep-HPLC with the following conditions: column, Chiralpak IA, 2 × 25 cm, 5 μm; mobile phase, Hex/EtOH (hold 50% ethanol over 28 min); detector, UV 220/254 nm. This resulted in the title compound (18 mg, 8.4% yield) and the undesired enantiomer (21 mg, 9.6% yield) both as white solids. HRMS m/z calcd for C20H20FN6O4 [M + H]+: 427.1525. Found: 427.1518. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.36 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.35–7.25 (m, 1H), 6.82–6.71 (m, 3H), 5.24 (s, 2H), 4.97 (dd, J = 5.8, 2.9 Hz, 1H), 4.56 (p, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 3.98 (s, 3H), 3.33 (s, 1H), 2.27–2.09 (m, 3H), 1.88–1.77 (m, 1H), 1.77 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 163.5 (d, J = 242.6 Hz), 159.1 (d, J = 11.5 Hz), 156.8, 153.9, 152.7, 151.8, 147.7, 145.7, 131.2 (d, J = 10.2 Hz), 115.1, 112.1 (d, J = 2.9 Hz), 107.7 (d, J = 21.7 Hz), 103.3 (d, J = 24.9 Hz), 77.9, 55.4, 40.7, 37.2, 33.9, 30.7, 28.8.

    1-(4-Chlorophenyl)but-3-en-1-ol (83)

    Allylmagnesium chloride (2.0 M in THF, 15.5 mL, 31.0 mmol) was added over 30 min to a solution of 4-chlorobenzaldehyde (3.43 mL, 28.2 mmol) in THF (28 mL) at 0 °C. The resulting mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 30 min and diluted with diethyl ether (25 mL), and the reaction was quenched with saturated aqueous NH4Cl (25 mL) and H2O (25 mL). The layers were separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with diethyl ether (3 × 50 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (50 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The obtained residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (5–20% gradient of ethyl acetate in hexanes) to afford the title compound (2.71 g, 53% yield) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.34–7.27 (m, 4H), 5.84–5.73 (m, 1H), 5.21–5.16 (m, 1H), 5.16–5.14 (m, 1H), 4.75–4.71 (m, 1H), 2.57–2.40 (m, 2H), 2.03 (d, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H).

    1-(4-Chlorophenyl)-2-(oxiran-2-yl)ethanol (84)

    m-CPBA (77%, 3.31 g, 14.8 mmol) was added portion-wise to a solution of alcohol 83 (2.71 g, 14.8 mmol) in DCM (48 mL) at 0 °C. The resulting mixture was allowed to warm to 20 °C and stirred for 18 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to 0 °C, diluted with DCM, and quenched with portion-wise addition of Ca(OH)2 (2.6 g, 29.6 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred for 2 h at 20 °C, the solid was filtered off, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to afford the title compound (2.79 g, 95% yield) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3, mixture of diastereomers) δ 7.35–7.29 (m, 4H), 4.96 (dd, J = 8.3, 5.0 Hz, 0.5H), 4.92 (dd, J = 9.0, 3.4 Hz, 0.5H), 3.19–3.13 (m, 0.5H), 3.05–2.99 (m, 0.5H), 2.83 (dd, J = 4.7, 4.1 Hz, 0.5H), 2.77 (dd, J = 4.8, 4.1 Hz, 0.5H), 2.62 (dd, J = 4.8, 2.8 Hz, 0.5H), 2.54–2.46 (m, 1.5H), 2.14 (ddd, J = 14.6, 9.0, 3.8 Hz, 0.5H), 2.06 (ddd, J = 14.3, 4.9, 4.0 Hz, 0.5H), 1.85–1.74 (m, 1H).

    5-(4-Chlorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-ol (85)

    Sulfuric acid (98%, 0.68 mL, 12.5 mmol) was added to a mixture of epoxide 84 (2.59 g, 13.0 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (130 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 16 h. The reaction mixture was poured on crushed ice, neutralized by the addition of saturated aqueous NaHCO3, and extracted with DCM (3 × 150 mL). Combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The obtained residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (10–50% gradient of ethyl acetate in hexanes) to afford the title compound (1.38 g, 53% yield) as a yellow oil. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3, mixture of diastereomers) δ 7.37–7.26 (m, 4H), 5.13 (dd, J = 10.2, 5.7 Hz, 0.56H), 4.91–4.86 (m, 0.44H), 4.67–4.55 (m, 1H), 4.24 (dd, J = 9.9, 4.4 Hz, 0.56H), 4.07–4.03 (m, 0.44H), 3.93–3.87 (m, 1H), 2.70–2.62 (m, 0.44H), 2.35–2.29 (m, 0.56H), 1.93–1.84 (m, 1H), 1.75 (d, J = 4.1 Hz, 0.56H), 1.63 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 0.44H).

    3-((3S,5R)-5-(4-Chlorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-yl)-5-((7-methyl-6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl)methyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2(3H)-one (19)

    To a solution of tetrahydrofuran 85 (200 mg, 1.01 mmol) in DMF (6.7 mL) were added oxadiazolone 34 (350 mg, 1.41 mmol) and triphenylphosphine (343 mg, 1.31 mmol). DIAD (0.26 mL, 1.3 mmol) was added dropwise at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 h. Ethyl acetate was added, and the mixture was washed with water and brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The product was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 0–10% MeOH in DCM to give 271 mg of a mixture of diastereomers as a white solid. The diastereomers were separated by semiprep LC–MS (conditions: CSH C18, 30 × 75 mm, 5 μm, 20–40% MeCN/10 mM ammonium formate (pH 3.8), 8 min, 45 mL/min). Relevant fractions were pooled, frozen, and lyophilized to afford the cis isomer (104 mg, 24% yield) and the trans isomer (87 mg, 20% yield). The racemic trans isomer was submitted to chiral separation (conditions: column, ChiralPak IB, 250 mm × 4.6 mm ID, 5 μm; eluant: 25:25:50 EtOH/DCM/Hex; flow isocratic: 0.8 mL/min, 51 bar; column temperature: 26 °C; injection time: 17 min, 1st product Rt =12.1 min, 2nd product Rt =14.1 min). Fractions of the second product to come out (Rt = 14.1 min) were pooled, frozen and lyophilized to provide the title compound (33 mg, 8% yield) as a white solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C19H18ClN6O4 [M + H]+: 429.1073. Found: 429.1063. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.36 (s, 1H), 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.43–7.38 (m, 2H), 7.38–7.32 (m, 2H), 5.26 (s, 2H), 5.07–5.01 (m, 1H), 4.84–4.76 (m, 1H), 4.32–4.25 (m, 1H), 3.97 (s, 3H), 3.96–3.89 (m, 1H), 2.61–2.53 (m, 1H), 2.17–2.04 (m, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSOd6) δ 156.8, 153.9, 152.8, 151.9, 147.7, 145.7, 141.2, 132.5, 128.8, 128.2, 115.1, 79.4, 71.1, 56.4, 39.3, 33.9. ee = 96.9% (ChiralPak IB, 250 mm × 4.6 mm ID, 5 μm; eluant: 25:25:50 EtOH/DCM/hexane; flow isocratic: 0.7 mL/min, 51 bar; column temperature: 26 °C; injection time: 25 min; Rt = 18.9 min).

    (R)-1-(4-Chlorophenyl)but-3-en-1-ol (87)

    In four separate pressure vessels were added each 4-chlorobenzaldehyde (100 g, 711 mmol), chloro(1,5-cyclooctadiene)iridium(i) dimer (14.3 g, 21.3 mmol), Cs2CO3 (46.3 g, 142 mmol), 4-chloro-3-nitro-benzoic acid (14.3 g, 71.4 mmol), and (R)-BINAP (22.1 g, 35.5 mmol). A flask was flushed with nitrogen before the addition of 1,4-dioxane (700 mL), allyl acetate (712 g, 7.11 mol), and i-PrOH (85.5 g, 1.42 mol, 109 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 112 °C for 20 h. TLC (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 5:1, Rf = 0.34) showed one new main spot. The four reactions were allowed to cool, combined together, and filtered to remove solid. The solid was rinsed with ethyl acetate (2 × 400 mL), and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 5:1) to deliver the title compound as a brown oil (414 g, 2.27 mol, 80% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.34–7.27 (m, 4H), 5.84–5.73 (m, 1H), 5.21–5.16 (m, 1H), 5.16–5.14 (m, 1H), 4.75–4.71 (m, 1H), 2.57–2.40 (m, 2H), 2.03 (d, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H).

    (R)-3,4-Dibromo-1-(4-chlorophenyl)butan-1-ol (89)

    A solution of Br2 (127 g, 793 mmol, 40.9 mL) in DCM (480 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of alcohol 87 (138 g, 756 mmol) in DCM (480 mL) at −30 °C. The resulting mixture was stirred for 1 h at −30 °C. Three reactions were carried out in parallel. TLC (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 5:1, Rf1 = 0.42, Rf2 = 0.31) showed that the starting material was consumed completely, and two new main spots appeared. The three reactions were combined together for workup. The reaction was quenched by the addition of a saturated aqueous solution of Na2S2O3 (3.00 L) and water (3.00 L). The reaction mixture was stirred vigorously at 20 °C. The resulting mixture was extracted with DCM (2 × 2.50 L). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (2 × 2.00 L), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo to deliver a diastereomeric mixture of the title compound as a brown oil (743 g, crude). The product was used in the next step without further purification. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.28 (d, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H), 7.27–7.20 (m, 2H), 4.98–4.83 (m, 1H), 4.55–4.41 (m, 0.5H), 3.85 (dd, J = 4.4, 10.4 Hz, 0.5H), 3.79–3.58 (m, 2H), 2.48–2.38 (m, 1H), 2.29–2.21 (m, 0.5H), 1.94–1.78 (m, 0.5H).

    (R)-4-Bromo-2-(4-chlorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran (91)

    To a solution of dibromide 89 (247 g, 721 mmol) in MeOH (1.70 L) was added K2CO3 (399 g, 2.89 mol) at 20 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at 20 °C for 12 h. Three reactions were carried out in parallel. TLC (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 5:1, Rf1 = 0.72, Rf2 = 0.56) showed that the starting material was consumed completely. The three reactions were combined for workup. The reaction mixture was cooled, and a saturated aqueous solution of NH4Cl (1.50 L) was added followed by water (1.50 L). The mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel, and it was extracted with ethyl acetate (2 × 3.0 L). The combined organic layers were washed with a mixture of water (3.00 L) and brine (3.00 L). The organic layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to deliver a diastereomeric mixture of the title compound as a brown oil (555 g, crude). The product was used in the next step without further purification. For analytical purposes, 3.5 g was purified by silica gel chromatography, eluting with 0–20% ethyl acetate in hexanes to afford the trans-diastereomer (1.34 g) as a colorless oil, which solidified to a white solid and the cis-diastereomer (912 mg) as a yellowish oil. trans-diastereomer: 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.37–7.29 (m, 4H), 5.28 (dd, J = 9.4, 5.9 Hz, 1H), 4.64–4.59 (m, 1H), 4.57 (dd, J = 10.3, 5.1 Hz, 1H), 4.28 (dd, J = 10.2, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 2.68 (ddd, J = 14.0, 5.9, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 2.29 (ddd, J = 14.0, 9.4, 6.2 Hz, 1H). cis-diastereomer: 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.38–7.31 (m, 4H), 4.90 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 4.49 (ddd, J = 11.3, 7.2, 5.3 Hz, 1H), 4.25–4.21 (m, 2H), 2.98 (dt, J = 13.9, 7.3 Hz, 1H), 2.25 (ddd, J = 14.0, 8.3, 6.1 Hz, 1H).

    (3R,5R)-5-(4-Chlorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-carbonitrile (93)

    A mixture of tetrahydrofuran 91 (170 g, 650 mmol) and KCN (112 g, 1.62 mol) in DMSO (1.20 L) was degassed and purged with N2 three times, and then the mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 20 h under an N2 atmosphere. Three reactions were carried out in parallel. TLC (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 5:1, Rf1 = 0.51, Rf2 = 0.21) showed conversion to a new spot. The three reactions were combined, cooled to 20 °C, and diluted with ethyl acetate (200 mL), and solids were filtered on a fritted funnel and washed with ethyl acetate (140 mL). The filtrate was transferred to a 10.0 L separatory funnel followed by the addition of water (4.00 L) and brine (800 mL). The layers were separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with more ethyl acetate (2 × 800 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with a mixture of water (800 mL) and brine (800 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to give an orange oil. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 50:1–5:1) to afford the title compound (102 g, 20% yield) and the undesired cis-diastereomer (120 g, 30% yield) both as yellow solids. Title compound: 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.35–7.32 (m, 2H), 7.26–7.23 (m, 2H), 5.09–5.02 (m, 1H), 4.38 (dd, J = 8.9, 7.6 Hz, 1H), 4.09–4.03 (m, 1H), 3.28–3.19 (m, 1H), 2.68–2.61 (m, 1H), 2.18–2.11 (m, 1H). cis-diastereomer: 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.37–7.33 (m, 2H), 7.33–7.28 (m, 2H), 4.86 (dd, J = 8.7, 6.7 Hz, 1H), 4.29 (dd, J = 9.0, 5.4 Hz, 1H), 4.12 (dd, J = 9.0, 7.7 Hz, 1H), 3.31–3.22 (m, 1H), 2.80–2.72 (m, 1H), 2.17–2.08 (m, 1H).

    5-(Chloromethyl)-3-((3R,5R)-5-(4-chlorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazole (95)

    A mixture of nitrile 93 (102 g, 491 mmol) and hydroxylamine (40.5 g, 1.23 mol) in EtOH (600 mL) was degassed and purged with N2 three times, and then the mixture was stirred at 83 °C for 2 h under an N2 atmosphere. The reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo to give a residue. The residue was added to MTBE (100 mL) and stirred for 1 h, and a white solid appeared. The mixture was filtered, and the filter cake was dried to afford (3R,5R)-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-N-hydroxytetrahydrofuran-3-carboximidamide (107 g, 91% yield) as a white solid.
    To a mixture of (3R,5R)-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-N-hydroxytetrahydrofuran-3-carboximidamide (89.8 g, 526 mmol) in MTBE (800 mL) was added chloroacetic anhydride (115 g, 478 mmol) at 0 °C and the mixture was purged with N2 three times. The mixture was stirred at 25 °C for 0.5 h under an N2 atmosphere. The solution was added to 500 mL saturated aqueous solution of NaHCO3. The resulting mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 250 mL), the combined organic layer was dried with anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. To the resulting yellow oil was added MTBE (300 mL), the resulting mixture was stirred 5 min and then cooled to −20 °C. The formed solid was collected on a Büchner funnel and rinsed with cold MTBE (−20 °C, 150 mL) to give (3R,5R,Z)-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)-5-(4-chlorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-carboximidamide as a white solid (120 g, 79% yield). The solid was used in the next step without further purification.
    A mixture of (3R,5R,Z)-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)-5-(4-chlorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-carboximidamide (135 g, 426 mmol) and activated 4 Å molecular sieves (135 g) in toluene (675 mL) was degassed and purged with N2 three times. The mixture was stirred at 120 °C for 2 h under an N2 atmosphere. HPLC and TLC (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 1:1, Rf = 0.60) showed full conversion. The reaction mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 25:1–5:1) to afford the title compound (82.0 g, 64% yield) as a yellow oil. LCMS, m/z = 299 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.35–7.29 (m, 4H), 5.14 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 4.69 (s, 2H), 4.47 (dd, J = 8.8, 7.6 Hz, 1H), 4.10 (dd, J = 8.8, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 3.79–3.73 (m, 1H), 2.72 (ddd, J = 12.5, 7.0, 5.3 Hz, 1H), 2.23 (ddd, J = 12.8, 9.0, 7.6 Hz, 1H).

    1-((3-((3R,5R)-5-(4-Chlorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-7-methyl-1H-purin-6(7H)-one (20)

    To a mixture of oxadiazole 95 (80.0 g, 267 mmol) and 7-methyl-1H-purin-6-one (60.2 g, 401 mmol) in DMF (560 mL) was added K2CO3 (111 g, 802 mmol) at 0 °C. The mixture was degassed, purged with N2 three times, and then stirred at 25 °C for 12 h under an N2 atmosphere. HPLC and TLC (DCM/MeOH = 10:1, Rf1 = 0.61) showed full conversion. EtOH (250 mL) was added at 0 °C before the addition of water (3.00 L), which resulted in a solid crashing out of solution. The solid was collected, washed with water (0 °C, 1.20 L), and air dried for 2 h. An amount of 87.0 g of the crude material was obtained as a white solid. A solution of EtOH (4.00 L) was heated, and when internal temperature reached 70 °C, the crude product (87.0 g) was added with a plastic funnel, rinsing with EtOH (200.0 mL) and water (175 mL). Full dissolution of the material was observed after 45 min with internal temperature at 75 °C. The mixture was then stirred at 79 °C for an additional 45 min. The mixture was cooled to 25 °C for 36 h and then cooled to 0 °C, causing a solid to crash out of solution. The solid was collected on a Büchner funnel, and the solid was rinsed with cold EtOH (0 °C, 500 mL). The solid was air dried for 5 h to afford the title compound as a white solid (75.0 g, 67% yield). HRMS m/z calcd for C19H18ClN6O3 [M + H]+: 413.1123. Found: 413.1117. HPLC purity: 99.53%. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.46 (s, 1H), 8.24 (s, 1H), 7.42–7.36 (m, 4H), 5.57 (s, 2H), 5.01 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 4.35 (dd, J = 8.6, 7.4 Hz, 1H), 3.96 (s, 3H), 3.90 (dd, J = 8.6, 6.3 Hz, 1H), 3.80–3.71 (m, 1H), 2.60–2.54 (m, 1H), 2.17–2.10 (m, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 175.5, 171.1, 156.5, 153.5, 147.3, 145.3, 141.3, 131.9, 128.3, 127.7, 114.6, 79.0, 71.0, 41.5, 38.4, 36.0, 33.4.

    (R)-1-(4-Fluorophenyl)but-3-en-l-ol (88)

    (R)-(+)-BINAP (12.9 g, 20.1 mmol), 4-chloro-3-nitrobenzoic (8.12 g, 40.3 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (26.3 g, 80.6 mmol) were charged in a 2 L two-necked flask. 1,4-Dioxane (671 mL), allyl acetate (43.5 mL, 403 mmol), isopropanol (62 mL, 806 mmol), and 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (43.2 mL, 402 mmol) were added. The flask was topped with a condenser and septum. Nitrogen was bubbled through the reaction mixture. A chloro(l,5-cyclooctadiene)iridium(i) dimer (6.83 g, 10.1 mmol) was added to the solution while bubbling, and the reaction was bubbled through for 10 more min. The reaction mixture was stirred at 112 °C for 27 h and cooled to room temperature, and the solids were filtered off. The filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The crude mixture was co-evaporated with toluene (2×). The crude was purified on a silica gel column (15 W × 15H). The product was loaded in a minimum amount of toluene and eluted with isopropyl acetate/heptane (2 L of each 3, 4, 6, 8, 10, 15, and 20%). An amount of 23 g of mixed fractions was repurified by silica gel column (5–20% isopropyl acetate/heptane). Another 7.3 g of mixed fractions was repurified using the same conditions to afford the title compound (58.3 g, 87% yield) as an orange oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.33–7.25 (m, 2H), 7.04–6.94 (m, 2H), 5.81–5.67 (m, 1H) 5.16–5.04 (m, 2H), 4.68 (dd, J = 7.28, 5.73 Hz, 1H), 2.52–2.37 (m, 2H), 2.27–2.13 (m, 1H).

    (R)-3,4-Dibromo-1-(4-fluorophenyl)butan-1-ol (90)

    A solution of bromine (16.3 mL, 317 mmol) in DCM (302 mL) was added dropwise over 1.5 h to a solution of alcohol 88 (50.2 g, 302 mmol) in DCM (755 mL) at −30 °C. The reaction was stirred at −30 °C for 30 min. The reaction was quenched with saturated Na2S2O3 (300 mL) and water (300 mL), and the reaction was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The phases were separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted (2×) with DCM. The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to afford a diastereomeric mixture of the title compound (96.9 g, 98% yield) as a crude brown oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.35–7.21 (m, 2H), 7.03–6.92 (m, 2H), 4.98–4.85 (m, 1H), 4.50 (dddd, J = 11.2, 9.1, 4.4, 2.3 Hz, 0.5H), 3.90–3.70 (m, 1.5H), 3.67–3.52 (m, 1H), 2.51–2.36 (m, 1H), 2.33–2.22 (m, 0.5H), 1.98–1.79 (m, 0.5H).

    (R)-4-Bromo-2-(4-fluorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran (92)

    K2CO3 (166 g, 1.19 mol) was added to a solution of dibromide 90 (96.9 g, 297 mmol) in MeOH (743 mL). A water bath at 20 °C was used to control the exotherm. The reaction was stirred at room temperature overnight. The reaction was cooled to 10 °C, and saturated NH4Cl (500 mL) was added followed by water (500 mL). The mixture was extracted with isopropyl acetate (3×) and washed with water and brine. The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to afford a diastereomeric mixture of the title compound (69.8 g, 96% yield) as a crude brown oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.44–7.20 (m, 2H), 7.10–6.95 (m, 2H), 5.25 (dd, J = 9.5, 6.0 Hz, 0.5H), 4.89 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 0.5H), 4.62–4.45 (m, 1.5H), 4.27–4.20 (m, 1.5H), 3.02–2.91 (m, 0.5H), 2.69–2.59 (m, 0.5H), 2.33–2.22 (m, 1H).

    (3R,5R)-5-(4-Fluorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-carbonitrile (94)

    KCN (57.4 g, 855 mmol) was added to a solution of tetrahydrofuran 92 (69.8 g, 285 mmol) in DMSO (570 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 105 °C for 15 h. The reaction mixture was allowed to cool down to room temperature. The excess KCN was removed by filtration, and the solids were washed with isopropyl acetate. The reaction mixture was partitioned in water/isopropyl acetate and extracted with isopropyl acetate (3×). The combined organic extracts were washed with water (2×) and brine, dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and then concentrated in vacuo. The crude mixture was purified by silica gel chromatography using a column of 15 cm (width) × 18 cm (height) eluting with isopropyl acetate in heptane (5, 7, 10, 12, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, and 40%) to afford the title trans nitrile (18.4 g, 34% yield) as a clear yellow oil. The cis nitrile, (3S,5R)-5-(4-fluorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-carbonitrile, was also obtained (15.7 g, 29% yield) as a clear yellow oil. Title compound: 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) 7.31−7.26 (m, 2H), 7.09−7.01 (m, 2H), 5.05 (dd, J = 8.0, 7.0 Hz, 1H), 4.39 (dd, J = 8.8, 7.7 Hz, 1H), 4.06 (dd, J = 8.9, 6.5 Hz, 1H), 3.30−3.20 (m, 1H), 2.64 (ddd, J = 12.9, 6.5, 4.7 Hz, 1H), 2.21−2.11 (m, 1H). cis-diastereomer: 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.31–7.20 (m, 2H), 7.05–6.92 (m, 2H), 4.78 (dd, J = 8.5, 6.7 Hz, 1H), 4.22 (dd, J = 8.9, 5.4 Hz, 1H), 4.08–3.97 (m, 1H), 3.19 (qd, J = 7.9, 5.5 Hz, 1H), 2.67 (ddd, J = 13.0, 8.4, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 2.05 (dt, J = 12.8, 8.2 Hz, 1H).

    5-(Chloromethyl)-3-((3R,5R)-5-(4-fluorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazole (96)

    Hydroxylamine (50 mass % in water) (49.5 mL, 808 mmol) was added to a solution of nitrile 94 (48.3 g, 202 mmol) in EtOH (505 mL). The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The mixture was purified on a pad of silica gel (10 cm wide × 7 cm height) using 100% DCM (1.5 L) to elute the impurities and then 10% MeOH/DCM (2 L) to elute the product. Some products came out in the first fraction; the other fractions were clean. The first fraction was concentrated aside and repurified. An amount of 19.6 g of mixed fractions was repurified by silica gel chromatography with 100% DCM and then 10% MeOH/DCM to afford (3R,5R)-5-(4-fluorophenyl)-N′-hydroxytetrahydrofuran-3-carboximidamide (36.4 g, 80% yield) as a blue gray gum.
    Chloroacetic anhydride (10.8 g, 60.1 mmol) was added portion-wise to a solution of (3R,5R)-5-(4-fluorophenyl)-N′-hydroxy-tetrahydrofuran-3-carboximidamide (12.3 g, 54.6 mmol) in MTBE (137 mL) at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 min. The reaction mixture was cooled to 0 °C, diluted with isopropyl acetate, and partitioned with saturated aqueous NaHCO3. The aqueous layer was extracted with isopropyl acetate (3×). The combined organic layers were washed with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 again and brine, dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and partially concentrated in vacuo. The solvent was swapped for MTBE and concentrated in vacuo until an oily residue was obtained. The product was triturated with MTBE (150 mL). The solution was cooled to −20 °C, and the formed solid was recovered by filtration and washed with MTBE at −20 °C. The product was dried under vacuum to afford (3R,5R,Z)-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)-5-(4-fluorophenyl) tetrahydrofuran-3-carboximidamide (11.9 g, 73% yield) as a white solid.
    A mixture of (3R,5R,Z)-N′-(2-chloroacetoxy)-5-(4-fluorophenyl) tetrahydrofuran-3-carboximidamide (36.0 g, 120 mmol) and 4 Å molecular sieve powder (40 g, preactivated in the oven) in toluene (479 mL) was stirred at 115 °C for 8 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature. The molecular sieves were removed by filtration and washed with isopropyl acetate. The filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The crude mixture was purified by silica gel chromatography eluting with 0–50% isopropyl acetate in heptane to afford the title compound (32.1 g, 95% yield) as a clear oil. LCMS, m/z = 282.9 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.37–7.31 (m, 2H), 7.09–6.99 (m, 2H), 5.14 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 4.69 (s, 2H), 4.47 (dd, J = 8.8, 7.6 Hz, 1H), 4.09 (dd, J = 8.8, 6.7 Hz, 1H), 3.83–3.72 (m, 1H), 2.71 (ddd, J = 12.5, 7.0, 5.3 Hz, 1H), 2.25 (ddd, J = 12.8, 9.1, 7.7 Hz, 1H).

    1-((3-((3R,5R)-5-(4-Fluorophenyl)tetrahydrofuran-3-yl)-1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)methyl)-7-methyl-1H-purin-6(7H)-one (21)

    7-Methyl-1H-purin-6-one (23.9 g, 159 mmol) and K2CO3 (47.6 g, 341 mmol) were added to a solution of oxadiazole 96 (32.1 g, 114 mmol) in DMF (227 mL) at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 6 h. The reaction was allowed to warm to room temperature overnight. EtOH (95 mL) was added at 0 °C followed by water (950 mL). The solid was recovered by filtration on a fritted funnel and washed with water at 0 °C. The solid was dried under vacuum for 15 min. The solid was dissolved in DCM, dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. Once a paste was obtained, DCM was swapped for isopropyl acetate and co-evaporated two times with 100 mL of isopropyl acetate. The residue was triturated with isopropyl acetate (415 mL), cooled to 0 °C, recovered by filtration, washed with cold isopropyl acetate, and dried under vacuum to afford the title compound (40.5 g, 90% yield) as an off-white solid. To recrystallize, the title compound was placed in a 1 L reactor and EtOH/water (7:3, 720 mL, 18 volumes) was added. The mixture was heated to 75 °C, and the material slowly dissolved over 40 min. At this point, the material was seeded with a suspension of crude material (1 g suspended in EtOH/water 1:1, 20 mL). The obtained suspension was left to age at 75 °C for 30 min. The suspension was then slowly cooled down to 25 °C over 2 h and then left at 25 °C for another hour. The material was filtered through a filter funnel, and the solid was washed with EtOH/water (1:1, 100 mL). The solid was air-dried, and then the material was left in the vacuum oven (60 °C overnight) with a slight stream of nitrogen to afford the title compound (36.2 g, 91% yield) as a white crystalline solid. HRMS m/z calcd for C19H18FN6O3 [M + H]+: 397.1419. Found: 397.1411. HPLC purity: 99.82%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.46 (s, 1H), 8.24 (s, 1H), 7.39 (dd, J = 8.5, 5.6 Hz, 2H), 7.16 (t, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 5.58 (s, 2H), 5.00 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H), 4.35 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 3.95 (s, 3H), 3.91–3.83 (m, 1H), 3.80–3.70 (m, 1H), 2.56 (ddd, J = 12.6, 7.1, 5.3 Hz, 1H), 2.15 (ddd, J = 12.7, 9.0, 7.7 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 175.5, 171.2, 161.5 (d, J = 242 Hz), 156.5, 153.5, 147.3, 145.3, 138.4 (d, J = 2.9 Hz), 127.8 (d, J = 7.7 Hz), 115.0 (d, J = 21.9 Hz), 114.6, 79.1, 70.9, 41.5, 38.5, 36.0, 33.4.

    Molecular Modeling

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The methods used for conformational analysis and quantum mechanical (QM) calculations have been described previously.(33) We selected the lowest energy conformation of compound 2 as a reference to align all other compounds. For each compound, a conformer with an energy less than 1.5 kcal/mol relative to the global minimum and the best overall alignment to the reference was chosen for evaluation. For compounds 3 and 9, additional QM torsional scans (geometry optimized using HF/6-31G* and single-point energy then calculated using MP2/6-311+G** in solvent) were performed at selected bonds using the Jaguar optimized QM conformations to find a low-energy conformation with the maximum overlap to the reference conformation of compound 2.(47)

    Pharmaceutical and Biological Assay Protocols

    Calcium Influx Dose–Response Assays

    The calcium influx assay was carried out as previously reported.(48) The assay buffer contained Hank’s balanced salt solution, 20 mM HEPES along with 0.02% BSA (pH readjusted to 7.4). A 384-well assay format using a fluorometric imaging plate reader (FLIPR) and a calcium assay kit (BD#640178) was developed. CHO cells stably expressing either human TRPA1 or rat TRPA1 were loaded with calcium dye and then incubated for 90 min with varying concentration of compounds. An EC80 concentration of cinnamaldehyde (75 mM and 45 mM for human and rat TRPA1, respectively) was employed to activate the channels and subsequently induce Ca2+ influx, as demonstrated by an increase in fluorescence signal. Concentration-dependent blocks were derived using the peak responses.

    Rat AITC Target Engagement Assay

    The experimental procedures involving animals were approved by Genentech’s Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. These procedures were conducted in accordance with the National Institutes of Health Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals as well as the recommendations of the International Association for the Study of Pain. Adult male Sprague–Dawley rats (300–350 g; Charles River, Hollister) were pair-housed and kept on a 14/10 h light/dark cycle with free access to food and water in a temperature-controlled environment. Rats were dosed using oral gavage with a vehicle (15% dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), 85% methylcellulose/Tween (MCT); 5 mL/kg) or compound and then returned to their home cages. Three hours post-dose, each rat was lightly restrained, and using a disposable 30-gauge needle and a Hamilton syringe equipped with luer tip, an intraplantar injection of 25 μL of a 0.1% solution of allylisothiocyanate (AITC) in mineral oil was made to one hind paw. Following injection, the rat was placed immediately into a plexiglass test chamber on a room temperature glass surface, and for 5 min, its behavior videotaped. The responses of up to six rats at a time were taped for offline scoring of nocifensive behavior, defined as lifting, licking, guarding, or shaking the injected paw. An experimenter who was blind to dose group performed the video scoring. Directly after the video session, the rats were removed from the test chambers and euthanized by CO2 inhalation, and then blood collection was performed via cardiac puncture. The whole blood samples were collected into test tubes containing ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), which were then centrifuged at 20,000g for 2 min. Finally, the plasma supernatant was isolated for analysis of the concentration of test compound.

    Ovalbumin (OVA) Challenge Model of Asthma in Guinea Pigs

    Hartley guinea pigs were immunized on days 0 and 7 by intraperitoneal administration of 100 mg OVA mixed with 80 mg of alum diluted in sterile PBS. Animals then received an OVA challenge on day 28 by exposure to 0.1% OVA in PBS for 30 min via a nebulizer. On day 28, compound 20 was dosed at 3, 10, and 30 mpk by gavage 2 h before and 8 h after the OVA challenge (BID) with dexamethasone as a positive control (5 mg/kg). 24 hours after the OVA challenge, guinea pigs were euthanized via intraperitoneal injection of Euthasol. Post-euthanasia, blood was collected from the abdominal aorta for PK analysis. Lungs were lavaged and cells collected for total and differential cell counts and FACS analysis. There was a minimum of five animals per group.

    Analysis of Bronchoalveolar Fluid (BALF)

    Lungs were lavaged with PBS. BAL cells were differentiated by microscopic analysis of methanol-fixed, Wright-Giemsa stained cytospin slides, or by flow cytometry. Red blood cells were lysed using ammonium-chloride potassium (ACK) lysis buffer and washed with FACS buffer. For cytospin analysis, a microscopic review and manual differential leukocyte count (200 cells) were performed on all Wright-Giemsa stained BAL cytospin preparations by a blinded clinical pathology laboratory technologist. The percentages of eosinophils, neutrophils, monocytes, basophils, and lymphocytes were calculated and reported. Cell counts were determined by FACS analysis using a known quantity of Fluoresbrite yellow green (YG) microspheres (Polysciences) as a spike-in standard and Sitox blue as a stain for dead cells.

    Experimental Drug Formulation

    For oral dosing, compound 20 was formulated by dissolving the compound in DMSO first (15% of the total target volume). After the compound was completely dissolved in DMSO, MCT (0.6% methylcellulose/0.2% Tween 80, 85% of the target volume) was added to the solution. The compound precipitated as amorphous material upon MCT addition.

    Cryogenic Electron Microscopy Methods

    Recombinant Expression and Purification of Truncated hTRPA1

    Recombinant human TRPA1 [Ser448–Thr1078] fused to a MBP affinity tag was expressed and purified as described previously.(52) Briefly, construct was cloned into a modified pAcGP67A vector downstream of the polyhedron promoter. The Baculogold system (BD Biosciences) was used to generate recombinant baculovirus following established protocols. Trichoplusia ni cells were infected for the production of protein and then harvested 48 h post-infection. Cell pellet was resuspended in lysis buffer (50 mM Tris pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 1 μg/mL benzonase, 0.5 mM TCEP, and Roche cOmplete protease inhibitor tablets), homogenized, lyzed, and spun down for 60 min at 40,000g. The membranes were solubilized at 4 °C in 25 mM Tris pH 8 with 150 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM TCEP, 10% glycerol, cOmplete protease inhibitor tablets, and 1% (w/v) FA-3 (Façade-EM, Avanti) for 2 h, and insoluble debris were removed by ultracentrifugation. The supernatant was collected for affinity purification by batch binding to amylose resin (3 mL) at 4 °C for 1 h. Resin was packed and washed with 5 CV of 25 mM Tris pH 8, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.5 mM TCEP with 0.06% FA-3 (Buffer A) and subsequently eluted with 3 CV of Buffer A with 40 mM maltose. A 100 kDa MWCO concentrator (Amicon Ultra-15 Centrifugal Filter Units, MilliporeSigma) was used to reduce down the elution fraction to 400 μL (∼4 mg/mL). PMAL-C8 (Anatrace, 100 mg/mL stock solution in water) in 3-fold excess (w/w) was added as well as some TEV protease and EndoF1 and EndoH deglycosidases (all prepared in-house). The sample was nutated overnight at 4 °C and then biobeads were added and incubated for 2 h at 4 °C. After filtering out the beads, the supernatant was transferred to a Superose 6 3.2/300 column pre-equilibrated with 25 mM Tris pH 8.2, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.5 mM TCEP. Finally, the sample (∼1 mg/mL) was incubated at 4 °C for 1 h with 100 μM of GNE551 (10 mM stock in DMSO).

    Cryo-EM Sample Preparation and Data Acquisition

    Holey carbon grids (Quantifoil, R0.6/1, 25 nm, Au, 300 mesh) were plasma etched for 3 s using the Solarus plasma cleaner (Gatan) in the hydrogen–oxygen setting. An amount of 1 μL of a solution of 0.48% fluorinated Fos choline was mixed with 3 μL of the sample and applied to a glow-discharged holey Au grid, incubated for 30 s, blotted in Vitribot Mark IV (Thermo Fisher) using a blotting time of 8 s with 100% humidity, and then plunge-frozen in liquid ethane (cooled by liquid nitrogen). Movie stacks were collected using SerialEM(49) on a Titan Krios operated at 300 keV with bioquantum energy filter operated with a 20 eV slit width and equipped with a K2 Summit direct electron detector camera (Gatan). Images were recorded at a magnification of 165,000×, corresponding to 0.824 Å/pixel, and with a set defocus range of 0.8–2.5 μm. Each image stack contained 40 frames recorded every 0.25 s for an accumulated dose of ∼50 e/Å2 and a 10 s total exposure time.

    Cryo-EM Data Processing

    The image processing from stacks of frames to a refined 3D volumetric map was accomplished with cisTEM.(50) All 8915 movies were motion-corrected and estimated for defocus parameters. Those movies with good CTF-to-Thon-ring fits up to a resolution of at least 3.75 Å (5,771 micrographs) were used for particle picking, yielding 395,169 candidate positions, which were classified into 100 two-dimensional classes, of which 21 exhibited high-contrast secondary structure features. The corresponding 101,265 particles were used for 3D reconstruction. An earlier 3D reconstruction of TRPA1 was used as a starting model for automatic refinement in cisTEM, using a mask to low-pass filter (but not otherwise attenuate) the nonprotein parts of the volume to a resolution of 20 Å. This refinement, using data up to 4.4 Å for orientation refinement, led to a map with an estimated resolution of 3.28 Å (FSC = 0.143). Following this, density modification was performed with Phenix,(51) using all-default parameter values, and yielding a map with estimated resolution of 3.05 Å (FSCref = 0.5), which was used for model refinement. For atomic model building, PDB: 6X2J(52) was rebuilt using interactive molecular dynamics in ISOLDE(53) and then refined in real space using Phenix(54) and Coot.(55) Map-model FSC was computed in Phenix using a cryoEM validation job type. The local resolution map was determined after a reimplementation of the algorithm of Cardone et al.(56)
